revision.text:
{{For|the band formerly known as 12 Gauge|Emerson Drive}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 12 Gauge | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Isiah Pinkney | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1968}} | birth_place = [[Augusta, Georgia]], [[United States|U.S.]] | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = [[Rapper]] | years_active = 1990s | label = [[Scotti Brothers Records|Scotti Bros.]]
[[Roadrunner Records|Roadrunner]] }} '''12 Gauge''' (born 1968) is an American [[rapper]] from [[Augusta, Georgia]]. Born '''Isiah Pinkney''', he started out as a [[DJ]], moving to rapping in the early 1990s, releasing three full-length albums. He is best known for his only top 40 single "[[Dunkie Butt]]", which peaked at 28 on [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and earned a gold certification. ==Discography== *''[[12 Gauge (12 Gauge album)|12 Gauge]]'' ([[Scotti Brothers Records|Scotti Bros.]], 1994) US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] peak #141, US R&B peak #44[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p143594|pure_url=yes}} Billboard], Allmusic.com *''Let Me Ride Again'' (Scotti Bros., 1995) *''Freaky One'' ([[Roadrunner Records]], 1998) ==Single== *"[[Dunkie Butt|Dunkie Butt (Please Please Please)]]" - [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] peak #28, Hot Rap Singles peak #3[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p143594|pure_url=yes}} Billboard Singles], Allmusic.com ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:12 Gauge}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:African-American male rappers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Musicians from Augusta, Georgia]] [[Category:Rappers from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Roadrunner Records artists]] [[Category:20th-century American rappers]] [[Category:21st-century American rappers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = 12th Planet | Birth_name = John Christopher Dadzie | background=non_vocal_instrumentalist | image = | caption = | birth_date= {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1982|6|7}} | origin = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States | genre = [[Dubstep]], [[Old school jungle|jungle]], [[drum and bass]], [[Trap music (EDM)|trap]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2013/09/12th-planet-prototype-papers-smog-records-track-stream/|title=Hear 12th Planet's Genre-Jumping Trap Burner 'Paper'|work=spin.com|date = September 13, 2013|last = Stolman|first = Elissa|publisher = Buzz Media}}</ref> | occupation = [[DJ]], [[Record producer]] | years_active = 2006 - Present | label = {{flatlist| * SMOG * Owsla * Disciple * Disciple Round Table }} | website = http://12thplanetofficial.com/ }} '''John Dadzie''', better known by his musical aliases '''12th Planet''' and '''Infiltrata''' is a [[Los Angeles]] based [[dubstep]] and [[drum and bass]] producer and DJ.
==Biography== Born John Christopher Dadzie, he grew up in South Los Angeles, the youngest of four children.<ref name="urb">{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/music/12th-planet-is-the-johnny-appleseed-of-dubstep-2174054 |title=12TH Planet is the Johnny Appleseed of Dubstep |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date = February 23, 2012|first = Liz|last = Ohanesian|website = laweekly.com}}</ref> He was first introduced to the electronic music scene in high school. After forming Imperial Recordings with DJ Lith, he launched his production skills on his own terms, originally producing [[drum and bass]] under the alias Infiltrata. In 2006, he decided that he was going to make [[dubstep]]. It was then that his new alias 12th Planet was created, in reference to [[Zecharia Sitchin]]'s book, 12th Planet. All production under the name 12th Planet is original.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thebigupmagazine.com/blog/about/music/12th-planet/ |title=12th Planet interview in Big magazine |publisher=thebigupmagazine.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314185607/http://thebigupmagazine.com/blog/about/music/12th-planet/ |archivedate=14 March 2012}}</ref> As one of the first individuals to bring the dubstep culture to America (in one of the USA's electronic meccas, [[Los Angeles]]) 12th Planet has frequently been cited as the General of the Riddim Gang.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.urb.com/2010/10/19/12-things-about-12th-planet-and-his-new-music-video-too/ |title=12 Things About 12th Planet (and his new music video too!) |publisher=URB |date=2010-10-19 |accessdate=2013-06-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130803201159/http://www.urb.com/2010/10/19/12-things-about-12th-planet-and-his-new-music-video-too/ |archivedate=3 August 2013}}</ref>
12th Planet worked frequently with Orange County producer Flinch and LA Local [[Skrillex]] (on tracks "Needed Change" And "Burst" Along with Kill The Noise). He has also collaborated with various dubstep producers including Datsik, Doctor P, [[Plastician]], [[Virtual Riot]] and [[Skream]]. Many well-known dubstep DJs (such as [[Rusko (musician)|Rusko]], [[Skream]], Skrillex and more) use 12th Planet's productions and remixes in their live DJ sets.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.madeyoulookradio.com/12th-planet-interview |title=12th Planet Interview « Made You Look Radio |publisher=Madeyoulookradio.com |date=2011-07-28 |accessdate=2013-06-23 |df= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509113732/http://www.madeyoulookradio.com/12th-planet-interview |archive-date=2012-05-09 |dead-url=yes }}{{cite web |url=http://www.madeyoulookradio.com/12th-planet-interview |title=12th Planet Interview « Made You Look Radio |publisher=Madeyoulookradio.com |date=2011-07-28 |accessdate=2013-06-23 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.madeyoulookradio.com/12th-planet-interview |title=12th Planet Interview « Made You Look Radio |publisher=Madeyoulookradio.com |date=2011-07-28 |accessdate=2013-06-23 |df= }} |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509113732/http://www.madeyoulookradio.com/12th-planet-interview |archivedate=9 May 2012</ref>
As a DJ, 12th Planet has toured globally in London, Sydney, Auckland, and across the US. He has also played at many American dance festivals such as [[Electric Daisy Carnival]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.electricdaisycarnival.com/archive/edc_2010/la/settimes.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101101114832/http://electricdaisycarnival.com/archive/edc_2010/la/settimes.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-11-01 |title=Friday June 25 & Saturday June 26th 2010 |publisher=Electric Daisy Carnival |date=2010-06-26 |accessdate=2013-06-23 }}</ref> Together As One,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyearsevela.com/2011/nye/bassrush.html |title=Bassrush Arena New Year's Eve |publisher=Newyearsevela.com |date=2010-12-31 |accessdate=2013-06-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121008235940/http://newyearsevela.com/2011/nye/bassrush.html |archivedate=2012-10-08 |df= }}</ref> [[SXSW]], [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]], [[Ultra Music Festival]], Nocturnal, and Beyond Wonderland. He is represented by AM Only, one of the largest agencies in the electronic music industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amonly.com|title=AM Only|work=AM Only}}</ref>
In 2007, 12th Planet helped in the re-launch and re-branding of SMOG Records, which was previously an event production company, and has since been its head.<ref>SMOG Records. [http://smogrecords.com/about-2/ "About: The SMOG Story"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521033130/http://smogrecords.com/about-2 |date=2014-05-21 }}. Retrieved on 16 May 2014.</ref> In 2009, 12th Planet was listed as one of URB.com's "Next 100", and had a special feature in their 25 Now! supplemental issue.<ref name="urb"/> 2010 marked the release of his music video for "Reasons", presented by [[Scion Audio/Visual|Scion]] A/V, which was premiered and cycled on [[MTV 2]].<ref>{{cite web|author=11/9/10 |url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/misc/595417/12th-planet-juakali-reasons.jhtml |title=12th Planet & Juakali 'Reasons' | Video |publisher=MTV |date= |accessdate=2013-06-23}}</ref> [[Diplo (DJ)|Diplo]]’s label [[Mad Decent]] included 12th Planet’s remix of [[Little Jinder]]'s "Youth Blood" on their [[dubstep]] compilation "Blow Your Head", released in November.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.beatport.com/en-US/html/content/home/detail/1/beatport#app=ab19&a486-index=2 |title=Beatport |publisher=Beatport |date= |accessdate=2013-06-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305212901/https://www.beatport.com/en-US/html/content/home/detail/1/beatport#app=ab19&a486-index=2 |archivedate=2009-03-05 |df= }}</ref> 12th Planet has also been described by Skrillex as Skrillex's Mentor at a show at Ultra Music
12th Planet finished in 20th place in the 2013 America's Best DJ competition-a vote and promotion to find out the country's most popular DJ conducted by ''[[DJ Times]]'' magazine and ''[[Pioneer Corporation|Pioneer DJ]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.djtimes.com/americasbestdj/2013-results/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140801165855/http://www.djtimes.com/americasbestdj/2013-results/ |archivedate=2014-08-01 |df= }}</ref>
In 2017, he signed with Myro and Dodge & Fuski's Disciple Recordings, becoming the head of the sub-label Disciple Round Table.<ref>https://ukf.com/news/12th-planet-joins-disciple/20012</ref><ref>https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7957100/12th-planet-disciple-round-table-send-it</ref>
==Discography==
===Singles / EPs === * 2008 RedVolume - '''''28 Hours Later''''' EP * 2008 SMOG 001 - '''''Smokescreen''''' EP * 2008 SMOG 002 - '''''Ptera Patrick''''' EP * 2008 BASSHEAD 001 - '''''Control''''' EP <small>(with Emu)</small> * 2008 SMOG 004 - '''''68 / Be Blatant''''' EP * 2008 Subconscious Recordings - '''''Spliff Politics''''' EP * 2008 Argon - '''''Element 16 (Sulfur)''''' EP * 2008 Noppa Recordings - '''''Tonka''''' EP * 2009 10 Bag Records - '''''C-Sick / Are Ya Feelin''''' EP <small>(with Emu)</small> * 2009 SMOG 005 - '''''Texx Mars''''' EP <small>(with [[Datsik (musician)|Datsik]])</small> * 2010 '''''Dubsteppers for Haiti Volume 3''''' * 2010 '''''SMOG Scion CD Sampler V.30''''' * 2010 Bullet Train Records - '''''Reasons''''' EP * 2011 SMOG 007 - '''''Westside Dub''''' <small>(with [[Plastician]])</small> * 2011 Dub Police - '''''Purple & Gold''''' <small>(with Antiserum)</small> * 2011 SMOG 009 - '''''Lootin 92''''' <small>(with [[SPL (DJ)|SPL]])</small> * 2011 SMOG 011 - '''''Who Are We?''''' * 2012 SMOG Records - '''''The End Is Near''''' EP * 2012 SMOG 023 - '''''The End''''' Album * 2013 SMOG 027 - '''''Whoops/Murdaaa''''' single <small>(with Mayhem)</small> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beatport.com/release/whoops-feat-pennybirdrabbit-murdaaa/1081344|title=Whoops (feat. Pennybirdrabbit) / Murdaaa [SMOG] :: Beatport|author=Beatport, LLC|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224091805/http://www.beatport.com/release/whoops-feat-pennybirdrabbit-murdaaa/1081344|archivedate=2013-12-24}}</ref> * 2013 SMOG 035 - '''''Transitions''''' EP <small>(with Protohype)</small><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00EZZRHL6/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-08-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140329033001/http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00EZZRHL6/# |archive-date=2014-03-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * 2016 SMOG 070 - '''''Name Bran''''' <small>(with LUMBERJVCK)</small><ref>https://www.beatport.com/release/name-bran/1691857</ref> * 2016 SMOG 074 - '''''Gully Squad''''' EP * 2017 Disciple Recordings - '''''Let Us Prey''''' EP * 2017 Knights of the Round Table Vol.1 - '''''Send It''''' Single <small>(with Barely Alive and PhaseOne)</small> * 2018 Disciple Alliance Vol.4 - '''''Slaughter Them All''''' Single <small>(with PhaseOne)</small> * 2018 Disciple Alliance Vol.4 - '''''Get Lemon''''' Single <small>(with Barely Alive, Dodge & Fuski, Eliminate, [[Fox Stevenson]], [[Hatcha]], [[Modestep]], Myro, Oolacile, [[Panda Eyes]], PhaseOne, [[Truth]] and [[Virtual Riot]])</small> * 2018 Disciple Round Table - '''''Bongo Boi''''' Single <small>(with Oolacile)</small><ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/bongo-boi-single/1430336917 |title=Bongo Boi - Single by 12th Planet & Oolacile on Apple Music |website=[[iTunes Store]] |accessdate=2018-08-27}}</ref> * 2018 Disciple Recordings - '''''Swamplex Terrestial''''' EP<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/swamplex-terrestrial-ep/1441353588 |title=Swamplex Terrestrial EP by 12th Planet on Apple Music |website=[[iTunes Store]] |accessdate=2018-11-23}}</ref>
===Mix Compilations=== * 2010 '''''MISHKA Keep Watch Volume XXI''''' <ref>http://mishkanyc.com/bloglin/2010/10/28/мишка-presents-keep-watch-vol-xxi-12th-planet/</ref>
===Remixes=== * 2009 Grand Puba - '''''Get It (12th Planet Remix)''''' [Scion A/V] * 2009 Dave Nada - '''''Apocalypse Theme (12th Planet & Flinch Remix)''''' [Tits & Acid] * 2009 Little Jinder - '''''Youth Blood (12th Planet & Flinch Remix)''''' [Trouble & Bass] * 2009 Ladybox - '''''Cookies Fly (12th Planet & Flinch Remix)''''' [Party Like Us] * 2010 Villains - '''''Victims (featuring [[Whiskey Pete]]) (12th Planet & Flinch Remix)''''' [Dim Mak] * 2010 [[Le Castle Vania]] - '''''Nobody Gets Out Alive (12th Planet & Flinch Remix)''''' [Always Never] * 2010 [[Rusko (musician)|Rusko]] - '''''Hold On (featuring Amber Coffman) (12th Planet Remix)''''' [Mad Decent] * 2010 [[DJ Sneak]] - '''''Southern Boy (12th Planet & Flinch Remix)''''' [Scion A/V] * 2010 [[Rye Rye]] - '''''Sunshine (featuring [[M.I.A. (artist)|M.I.A.]]) (12th Planet Remix)''''' [Interscope] * 2010 [[MSTRKRFT]] - '''''Heartbreaker (12th Planet & Flinch Remix)''''' * 2011 [[Skrillex]] - '''''All I Ask of You (featuring Penny) (12th Planet ft. Skrillex Remix)''''' * 2011 Echo Park - '''''Fiber Optic (12th Planet & Flinch Remix)''''' * 2012 [[Foreign Beggars]] feat. [[Donae'o]] - '''''Flying To Mars (12th Planet's Martian Trapstep Remix)''''' [mau5trap] * 2012 [[Dirtyphonics]] - '''''DIRTY (12th Planet Remix)''''' [Dim Mak] * 2013 [[Felguk]] - '''''Slice & Dice (12th Planet Remix)''''' * 2013 [[Pretty Lights]] - '''''Go Down Sunshine (12th Planet Remix)''''' * 2016 [[Pegboard Nerds]] - '''''Heartbit (12th Planet Remix)''''' * 2018 [[What So Not]] and [[San Holo]] - '''''If You Only Knew (featuring Daniel Johns) (12th Planet Remix)'''''
===As featured artist=== * 2010 [[Skrillex]] - "Needed Change" from the release '''''Skrillex Presents Free Treats Volume 001'''''.<ref>http://www.discogs.com/Various-Free-Treats-Volume-001/release/3153851</ref> * 2011 [[Skrillex]] - "Right On Time" (collaboration with [[Skrillex]] and [[Kill the Noise]]) from the [[extended play|EP]] '''''[[Bangarang (album)|Bangarang]]'''''. * 2011 [[Korn]] - "[[Way Too Far]]" (featured with [[Kill the Noise]]) from the album '''''[[The Path of Totality]]'''''.<ref>https://www.amazon.com/Path-Totality-Special-Explicit/dp/B006BZ8WAI/ref=sr_1_8?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1321996678&sr=1-8</ref> * 2013 Protohype - "Like This" (collaboration with Protohype) from the [[extended play|EP]] '''''Speak No Evil'''''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beatport.com/release/speak-no-evil/1177943|title=Speak No Evil [Firepower Records] :: Beatport|author=Beatport, LLC|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox non-profit | Non-profit_name = 2045 Initiative | Non-profit_logo = | Non-profit_type = | founded_date = {{start date and age|2011|2}} | founder = [[Dmitry Itskov]] | location = Moscow, Russia | origins = | key_people = [[Dmitry Itskov]] (Managing Director) | area_served = Global | product = | focus = Life extension | method = Avatar Project | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = Dmitry Itskov | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.2045.com/}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} {{Cyborg}} The '''2045 Initiative''' is a [[nonprofit organization]] that develops a network and community of researchers in the field of [[life extension]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://motherboard.vice.com/blog/russian-billionaire-dmitry-itskov-plans-on-becoming-immortal-by-2045 |title=Russian Billionaire Dmitry Itskov Plans on Becoming Immortal by 2045 |last=Eördögh |first=Fruzsina |publisher=Vice |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150524041430/http://motherboard.vice.com/blog/russian-billionaire-dmitry-itskov-plans-on-becoming-immortal-by-2045 |archivedate=2015-05-24 }}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.levif.be/info/actualite/sciences/ces-milliardaires-qui-revent-d-acheter-l-immortalite/article-4000497533046.htm |title=Ces milliardaires qui rêvent d'acheter l'immortalité [These millionaires dream of buying immortality] |publisher=Le Vif }}</ref> It was founded by Russian entrepreneur [[Dmitry Itskov]] in February 2011 with the participation of Russian specialists in the field of neural interfaces, robotics, artificial organs and systems.
The main goal of the 2045 Initiative, as stated on site, is "to create technologies enabling the transfer of an individual’s personality to a more advanced non-biological carrier, and extending life, including to the point of immortality. We devote particular attention to enabling the fullest possible dialogue between the world’s major spiritual traditions, science and society".
==Future prospects== The 2045 Initiative has a roadmap for developing cybernetic [[immortality]].<ref name = social>[http://2045.com/ideology/ About Us, Strategic Social Initiative, 2045]</ref> The Initiative has the goal for an avatar controlled by a "brain-computer" interface to be developed between 2015 and 2020, between 2020 and 2025 creating an autonomous life-support system for the human brain linked to a robot, between 2030 and 2035 creating a computer model of the brain and human consciousness with the means to transfer it into an artificial carrier, and by 2045 create a new era for humanity with holographic bodies.<ref name = social/>
==Avatar Project==
One of the featured [[Life extension|life-extension]] projects is to design an artificial [[humanoid]] body (called an "avatar") and an advanced [[brain–computer interface]] system. On the biological side, a life support system will be developed for hosting a human brain inside the avatar and maintaining it alive and functional. A later phase of the project will research into the creation of an [[artificial brain]] into which the original individual [[consciousness]] may be transferred.
=== Avatar A ===
A robotic copy of a human body remotely capable of interpreting commands directly from the mind, and sending information back to the mind in a form that can be interpreted via [[brain–computer interface]]. It is estimated to be popularized in or before 2020.
=== Avatar B ===
An avatar in which a human brain is [[Brain transplant|transplanted]] at the end of one's life. Avatar B has an autonomous system providing life support for the brain and allowing it interaction with the environment, possibly mounted into an existing Avatar A Chassis. Deadline of this phase is year 2025.
=== Avatar C ===
An avatar with an artificial brain to which a human personality is transferred for emulation at the end of one's life. The first successful attempt to upload one's personality to a computer is estimated to happen around 2035.
=== Avatar D ===
A [[Holography|hologram]]- or [[diagram]]-like avatar. This is the ultimate goal of this project but is optional since, assuming either the upload is involuntary or all humans chose to upload, biological diseases are prevented in the previous phase, and it is far away from current technological achievement and our understanding on physics.
==Reception==
Professor [[George M. Church]] has complained that "there's a lot of dots that aren't connected in (Itskov's) plans. It's not a real road map." [[Martine A. Rothblatt]], the founder of [[United Therapeutics]], has claimed the Avatar Project is "no more wild than in the early '60s, when we saw the advent of [[liver transplantation|liver]] and [[Kidney transplantation|kidney]] transplants."<ref name=nytimes_06_2013>{{cite news|last=Segal|first=David|title=Dmitry Itskov and the Avatar Quest|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/02/business/dmitry-itskov-and-the-avatar-quest.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=9 October 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=1 June 2013}}</ref>
==See also== {{colbegin}} * [[Brain transplant]] * [[Cyborg]] * [[Exocortex]] * [[Human enhancement]] * [[Isolated brain]] * [[Transhumanism]] {{colend}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://2045.com}} *[http://gf2045.com Global Future 2045 Congress]
{{Life extension}} {{BCI}}
[[Category:Biogerontology]] [[Category:Immortality]] [[Category:Life extension organizations]] [[Category:Neurotechnology]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Russia]] [[Category:Transhumanist organizations]]

{{pp-blp|expiry=22:40, 30 August 2019|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}}{{Infobox musical artist | name = 21 Savage | image = 21 Savage 2018.jpg | caption = 21 Savage performing in Austin, Texas in June 2018. | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1992|10|22|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]], U.S. | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] * [[Trap music|trap]] * [[gangsta rap]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * Rapper * singer * songwriter * record producer }} | instrument = Vocals | years_active = {{start date|2014}}–present | label = {{flatlist| * Slaughter Gang * [[Epic Records|Epic]] }} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Metro Boomin]] * [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] * [[Southside (record producer)|Southside]] * [[Sonny Digital]] * [[Zaytoven]] }} | website = {{URL|21savage.com}} }}
'''Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph''' (born October 22, 1992), better known by his stage name '''21 Savage''', is an American [[rapper]], record producer, and songwriter from [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. Abraham-Joseph grew up around criminality and eventually dropped out of school, beginning to rap in 2013 after the death of a friend. He gained attention in the [[Atlanta]] underground for the 2015 mixtape ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'' before attaining nationwide attention following the [[Metro Boomin]] collaborative album ''[[Savage Mode]]'' (2016), its lead single "[[X (21 Savage and Metro Boomin song)|X]]", and his collaboration with Drake, "[[Sneakin']]".<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.interviewmagazine.com/music/21-savage-seth-rogen-interview|title=21 Savage chops it up with Seth Rogen|date=2018-04-26|work=Interview Magazine|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
Abraham-Joseph released his debut studio album, ''[[Issa Album]]'', in 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/the-break/2015/10/the-break-presents-21-savage/|title=The Break Presents: 21 Savage|last=C.M.|first=Emmanuel|date=October 9, 2015|work=[[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]]|accessdate=May 2, 2018}}</ref> which debuted at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200 and gave Abraham-Joseph his first top twenty song, "[[Bank Account (song)|Bank Account]]." He achieved his first number one single at the end of 2017 with his feature on [[Post Malone]]'s "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]."<ref name="XXL Magazine2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/10/post-malone-21-savage-rockstar-no-1-billboard-hot-100-chart/|title=Post Malone's ''Rockstar'' Hits No. 1 on Billboard Hot 100 Chart|website=XXL Magazine|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In 2017, he also released the [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] and Metro Boomin collaboration ''[[Without Warning (21 Savage, Offset and Metro Boomin album)|Without Warning]]''.
==Early life== Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph was born on October 22, 1992, in Atlanta, Georgia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/21-savage-mn0003515232/biography|title=Biography & History|last=Jeffries|first=David|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=February 22, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Birthplace2">{{cite web|url=https://schedule.sxsw.com/2016/events/event_MS37401|title=21 Savage|author=<!--Not stated-->|website=[[South by Southwest]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> He was raised by his mother Heather, who is of [[People of Dominica|Dominica]] descent, and his four brothers and six sisters, though one is deceased due to a shooting after a [[Illegal drug trade|drug deal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://djbooth.net/features/2016-11-22-brutal-story-behind-21-savage-dagger-face-tattoo|title=The Brutal Story Behind 21 Savage's Dagger Face Tattoo|last=James|first=Andy|date=November 22, 2018|website=[[DJBooth]]|access-date=May 2, 2018|quote=}}</ref>
In the seventh grade, Abraham-Joseph was banned permanently from every school in the [[DeKalb County School District]] due to gun possession.<ref>{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v1CmVcwIyKo|title=21 Savage Interview With The Breakfast Club (8-4-16)|date=August 4, 2016|people=[[Charlamagne tha God]], [[DJ Envy]]|publisher=[[The Breakfast Club (radio show)]]|location=[[New York City]]|access-date=May 6, 2018|medium=Video}}</ref> This led him to begin attending schools around the [[Atlanta metropolitan area]] before being sent to a youth detention center.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/everything-you-need-to-know-about-21-savage-news.22853.html|title=Everything You Need To Know About 21 Savage|work=HotNewHipHop|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref> After being released from the youth detention center, he completed eighth grade through an alternative program before finishing a semester of high school, dropping out in his freshman year following multiple exclusions which Abraham-Joseph said he was "exhausted" by.<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/08/04/21-savage-the-breakfast-club-interview|title=21 Savage Talks Being An "A" Student, Losing His Best Friends On The Breakfast Club|work=The FADER|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref>
After dropping out, Abraham-Joseph joined a gang affiliated with the [[Bloods]]<ref name=":2" /> and became a full-time drug dealer, mainly selling cannabis.<ref name=":02" /> He also took parts in other criminal activities including robbery and grand theft auto regularly, though only being arrested once after contraband was found in a car he was driving.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=https://www.gq.com/story/21-savage-profile-2018|title=21 Savage: From Robbin’ Season to Role Model|last=Wood|first=Samuel Hine, Geordie|date=2018-06-27|work=GQ|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> In 2011, when Abraham-Joseph was 19, he lost his "right hand" man, Larry in a shootout.<ref name=":02" /> In 2013, on his 21st birthday, Abraham-Joseph was shot six times and his brother Johnny "Tay-Man" was killed during an attempted robbery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2015/10/01/feature-21-savage|title=Meet 21 Savage, Atlanta’s Most Respected New Rapper|website=[[The Fader]]|access-date=August 24, 2017}}</ref>
==Career== ===2014–15: Early releases=== Following the death of his friend in a shootout on his 21st birthday, Abraham-Joseph began rapping, naming himself after the event<ref name=":12" /> though Savage came from Instagram predictions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.capitalxtra.com/features/facts/21-savage/|title=19 Facts You Need To Know About 'Rockstar' Rapper 21 Savage|work=Capital XTRA|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> His music career was originally subsidized by the uncle of his deceased friend, giving him money for studio time in 2013.<ref name=":2" /> On November 12, 2014, 21 Savage's debut single, "Picky", produced by DJ Plugg, was released. It was later included on his debut mixtape, ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'', which was released on May 25, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemixtapes.com/mixtapes/34127/21-savage-the-slaughter-tape.html|title=21 Savage - The Slaughter Tape|work=LiveMixtapes|accessdate=April 27, 2016}}</ref> The release made him what [[Interview (magazine)|Interview]] called an "underground hero in Atlanta."<ref name=":2" />
On July 2, 2015, 21 released a collaborative EP, ''Free Guwop'', with [[Sonny Digital]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemixtapes.com/mixtapes/35036/21-savage-free-guwop-ep.html|title=21 Savage - Free Guwop EP|work=LiveMixtapes|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> It is a tribute EP to fellow rapper and influence [[Gucci Mane]]. On December 1, 2015, Abraham-Joseph released his second mixtape, ''[[Slaughter King]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/21-savage-slaughter-king-new-mixtape.116157.html|title=21 Savage - Slaughter King - Download & Listen [New Mixtape]|author=Rose Lilah|date=2 December 2015|work=HotNewHipHop|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
===2016–present: ''Savage Mode'', ''Issa Album'' and ''Without Warning''=== [[File:21 Savage 2018 2.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:21%20Savage%202018%202.jpg|left|thumb|21 Savage in June 2018]] In June 2016, Abraham-Joseph was named as one of the "Freshman Class" of 2016 by ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2016/06/xxl-freshman-class-cover-2016/|title=XXL Freshman Class Cover 2016|last=|first=|date=June 13, 2016|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=[[Townsquare Media]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> On July 15, 2016, Abraham-Joseph released his joint [[Extended play|EP]] [[Savage Mode]] with Atlanta-based record producer [[Metro Boomin]]. The EP gained international success and peaked at number 23 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], which became their highest charting EP to date.<ref name="BB2002">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/7447109/21-savage/chart|title=21 Savage – Chart History: Billboard 200|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016}}</ref> He was on the cover of [[Fader (magazine)|''Fader'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/21-savage-and-futures-x-is-now-platinum-news.25668.html|title=21 Savage on the cover of Fader|last=Lilah|first=Rose|access-date=23 November 2016}}</ref> His single "[[X (21 Savage and Metro Boomin song)|X]]" featuring [[Future (rapper)|Future]] on the EP was confirmed by Billboard as going platinum in the US, being 21's 1st platinum record.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2016/11/21-savage-first-platinum-record-x/|title=21 Savage Gets His First Platinum Record With "X"|last=Weinstein|first=Max|date=November 22, 2016|website=|publisher=|accessdate=December 3, 2016}}</ref> On January 18, 2017, Abraham-Joseph announced that he had signed to [[Epic Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/news/id.42064/title.21-savage-inks-record-deal-with-epic-records#|title=21 Savage Inks Record Deal With Epic Records|accessdate=January 18, 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, his debut studio album, ''[[Issa Album]]'', reached at number two on the US ''Billboard'' 200 chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7866158/21-savage-haim-billboard-200-albums-chart-top-10|title=21 Savage & Haim Debut in Top 10 on Billboard 200 Albums Chart|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|date=July 16, 2017|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> Its lead single, "[[Bank Account (song)|Bank Account]]", charted in the top 20 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://headlineplanet.com/home/2017/08/08/hot-100-niall-horans-slow-hands-enters-top-15-21-savages-bank-account-top-20/|title=Hot 100: Niall Horan’s "Slow Hands" Enters Top 15, 21 Savage’s "Bank Account" Top 20|date=August 7, 2017|work=Headline Planet|access-date=August 9, 2017}}</ref> Later that year, he was featured on [[Post Malone]]'s single "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]", which peaked at number one on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, and broke several records.<ref name="XXL Magazine2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/01/post-malone-rockstar-breaks-spotify-global-record/|title=Post Malone Breaks Spotify Global Record With ''Rockstar'' - XXL|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=2018-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8031270/post-malone-rockstar-platinum-21-savage|title=Post Malone & 21 Savage's 'Rockstar' Is Now Certified Platinum|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-02-16}}</ref>
In April 2018, Abraham-Joseph had a guest appearance on [[Young Thug]]'s extended play ''[[Hear No Evil (Young Thug EP)|Hear No Evil]]'' along with fellow rappers [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Lil Uzi Vert]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/04/13/young-thug-hear-no-evil-nicki-minaj-21-savage|title=Young Thug drops Hear No Evil EP|last=Maicki|first=Salvatore|date=April 13, 2018|website=The Fader|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> Later that month he also appeared on the single "Outstanding" by [[SahBabii]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/04/sahbabii-21-savage-new-song-outstanding/|title=Listen to SahBabii and 21 Savage's New Song "Outstanding"|last=India|first=Lindsey|date=April 20, 2018|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In March 21 he was featured on the single "Rover 2.0", which is part of [[BlocBoy JB]]'s [[Simi (mixtape)|Simi]] mixtape.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.stereogum.com/1988300/blocboy-jb-rover-2-0-feat-21-savage/music/|title=BlocBoy JB – "Rover 2.0" (Feat. 21 Savage)|last=Breihan|first=Tom|date=March 23, 2018|website=[[Stereogum]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|access-date=May 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/05/blocboy-jb-simi-mixtape/|title=BlocBoy JB Drops 'Simi' Mixtape Featuring Drake, Lil Pump and More|last=Coleman II|first=C. Vernon|date=May 4, 2018|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=May 9, 2018}}</ref> In the following month, he was featured on [[Ty Dolla Sign]]'s "Clout", which is part of the upcoming deluxe edition of last years's ''[[Beach House 3]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Darville|first=Jordan|date=May 9, 2018|title=Ty Dolla $ign recruits 21 Savage for "Clout"|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/05/09/ty-dolla-sign-21-savage-clout|magazine=The Fader|location=New York City|access-date=May 11, 2018}}</ref>
On October 31, 2018, [[Halloween]], Abraham-Joseph posted on his Instagram a picture of a man in silhouette jumping in the air in the direction away from a large blaze. In the bottom right corner of the picture there is a "Parental Advisory" notice, as there oftentimes is on the cover of rap releases. Abraham-Joseph also tagged Metro Boomin in the post. For these reasons, some speculated it to be a sequel to 2017's ''Without Warning'' record. However, it turned out to be the cover for Metro’s debut solo album, ''[[Not All Heroes Wear Capes]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BpnfcqeBtAT/?hl=en&taken-by=21savage|title=Saint Laurent Don on Instagram: "y’all know what season it is @metroboomin 4L"|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref>
== Musical style == Called "one of the last street niggas left making music" by frequent collaborator Metro Boomin,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2015/10/01/feature-21-savage|title=Meet 21 Savage, Atlanta’s Most Respected New Rapper|work=The FADER|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> Abraham-Joseph's music is heavily autobiographic with emphasis on violent and criminal aspects of his past including murder and drug dealing.<ref name=":12" />
==Controversies== In 2018, 21 Savage reportedly started a movement called "Guns Down, Paintballs Up" which was intended to reduce gun violence.<ref name="CBS2">{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/paintball-wars-initially-intended-to-curb-gun-violence-linked-to-2-deaths/|title="Paintball wars," initially intended to curb gun violence, linked to 2 deaths|last=Diaz|first=Adriana|date=May 1, 2018|website=[[CBS News]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> The head of the [[Detroit Police Department]], [[James Craig (police chief)|James Craig]], described the movement as "well-intentioned, however, misguided".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/paint-up-guns-down-detroit-paintball-arrests-2018-04-27/|title=Detroit police cracks down on citywide "paintball wars"|author=<!--Not stated-->|date=April 21, 2018|website=CBS News|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/04/27/detroit-police-crack-down-citywide-paintball-wars/560019002/|title=Detroit police to crack down on citywide 'paintball wars'|last1=Patterson|first1=Brandon|last2=Zaniewski|first2=Ann|date=April 27, 2018|website=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> The movement has been linked to several cases of property crime and homicide.<ref name="CBS2" /><ref name="USA Today2">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/05/01/paintball-wars-spate-shootings/569407002/|title=Paintball shootings splatter cities after rapper calls for swapping handguns for paintball weapons|last1=Mensch|first1=Jessica|last2=Luthern|first2=Ashley|date=May 1, 2018|website=USA Today|publisher=Gannett Company|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> 21 Savage has not commented on the matter, although he paid for the funeral of a 3-year old who was killed in a related incident.<ref name="CBS2" /><ref name="USA Today2" />
Controversy arose after Abraham-Joseph pulled out a firearm during a pool party on June 11, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8460380/21-savage-gun-atlanta-brawl|title=21 Savage Draws Gun During Atlanta Pool Party Brawl|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> Abraham-Joseph was given the firearm by a friend after seeing an opposing crew member also pull out a pistol.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vibe.com/2018/06/21-savage-pull-out-a-gun/|title=21 Savage Pulls Out A Gun During A Brawl: Watch|date=2018-06-10|work=Vibe|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref>
==Personal life== Abraham-Joseph practices the African religion [[Ifá]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_us/article/zn4pn3/21-savage-breakfast-club-interview-2016|title=No Joke, You Should Definitely Watch 21 Savage's Entire 'Breakfast Club' Interview|last=Witmer|first=Phil|date=August 4, 2016|website=[[Noisey]]|publisher=[[Vice Media]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/11/21/21-savage-cover-story-interview|title=Savage World|last=Barshad|first=Amos|date=November 21, 2016|website=The Fader|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pulse.ng/gist/21-savage-the-hottest-rapper-in-america-worships-ifa-id5816327.html|title=21 Savage, the hottest rapper in America worships Ifa|last=Tayo|first=Ayomide O.|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> In summer 2017, Savage started dating model [[Amber Rose]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/02/amber-rose-sniffs-21-savages-underwear/|title=Amber Rose Sniffs 21 Savage's Underwear When She Misses Him|last=Coleman II|first=C. Vernon|date=February 10, 2018|work=XXL Magazine|accessdate=February 10, 2018|publisher=Townsquare Media}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bet.com/music/2018/02/14/21-savage-valentines-day-gift-amber-rose.html|title=21 Savage Got The Sexiest Gift From Amber Rose For Valentine's Day|date=February 14, 2018|work=[[BET]]|accessdate=March 16, 2018}}</ref> As of March 2018, the couple has separated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/music/amber-rose-21-savage-split/|title=Amber Rose and 21 Savage Split After Nearly 2 Years of Dating|last1=Mizoguchi|first1=Karen|last2=Rubenstein|first2=Janine|date=March 14, 2018|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref>
He also has three children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalxtra.com/features/facts/21-savage/does-have-kids/|title=Does 21 Savage have any kids?|author=<!--Not stated-->|website=[[Capital XTRA]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref>
== Filmography == 21 Savage is currently working on his first movie, "'''''Issa Movie'''''".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ballerstatus.com/2017/12/10/21-savage-delivers-trailer-issa-movie/|title=21 Savage Delivers Trailer for "ISSA" Movie|date=2017-12-10|work=BallerStatus.com|access-date=2018-11-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
21 Savage also worked on a [[YouTube]] [[miniseries]] named "'''''Year 2100'''''".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/06/21-savage-animated-web-series-the-year-2100/|title=21 Savage Gets Animated in New Web Series ‘The Year 2100’ - XXL|website=XXL Mag|language=en|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main|21 Savage discography}}
===Studio albums===
* ''[[Issa Album]]'' (2017) * ''[[Without Warning (21 Savage, Offset and Metro Boomin album)|Without Warning]]'' {{small|(with [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] and [[Metro Boomin]])}} (2017)
===Extended plays===
* ''[[Free Guwop]]'' (2015) * ''[[Savage Mode]]'' {{small|(with Metro Boomin)}} (2016)
===Mixtapes===
* ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'' (2015) * ''[[Slaughter King]]'' (2015)
==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Award !Category !Nominated Work !Result |- | rowspan="10"| 2018 | [[BET Awards 2017|BET Awards]] | [[BET Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] | rowspan="2"|Himself | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[2018 iHeartRadio Music Awards|iHeartRadio Music Awards]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8240363/iheartradio-music-award-winners-2018-complete-list-winners-1089542|title=iHeartRadio Music Award Winners 2018: Complete List|last=Atkinson|first=Katie|date=March 11, 2018|work=Billboard|access-date=March 11, 2018}}</ref> | Best New Hip-Hop Artist | {{nom}} |- | Hip-Hop Song of the Year | "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]" {{small|(with [[Post Malone]])}} | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="5" |[[2018 Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/bbma/8343598/billboard-music-awards-2018-nominations-list|title=Billboard Music Awards 2018 Nominations: See the Full List|date=April 17, 2018|work=Billboard|access-date=April 17, 2018}}</ref> |[[Billboard Music Award for Top New Artist|Top New Artist]] |Himself |{{nom}} |- |[[Billboard Music Award for Top Hot 100 Song|Top Hot 100 Song]] | rowspan="6" | "Rockstar" {{small|(with Post Malone)}} | {{nom}} |- |[[Billboard Music Award for Top Streaming Song (Audio)|Top Streaming Song (Audio)]] | {{nom}} |- |Top Collaboration | {{nom}} |- |[[Billboard Music Award for Top Rap Song|Top Rap Song]] | {{won}} |- | [[ASCAP Awards|ASCAP Pop Awards]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/news-events/awards/2018/pop-awards|title=2018 Ascap Pop Awards|website=ASCAP|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> | Winning Songs | {{nom}} |- | [[2018 MTV Video Music Awards|MTV Video Music Awards]] | Song of the Year | {{won}} |}

{{autobiography|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 3D Na'Tee | image = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Samantha Davon James | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|12|18}} | birth_place = [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]] | origin = [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]] | death_date = | death_place = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = [[Rapping|Rapper]] | instrument = | years_active = 1994–present | label = Already Legendary, BMB | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|www.3DNATEE.com}} }}
'''Samantha Davon James''' (born December 18, 1986), better known by her stage name '''3D Na'Tee''', is an American [[rapper]], songwriter, and video director. She was born in [[New Orleans, Louisiana]] and grew up in the [[3rd Ward of New Orleans|3rd Ward]]. 3D Na'Tee has been featured on several national media outlets such as [[MTV]],<ref>{{cite web|title=MTV: SuckaFree Freestyle: 3D Na'Tee|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/misc/651008/sucker-freestyle-3dnatee.jhtml|accessdate=May 8, 2011}}</ref> [[The Source (magazine)|The Source Magazine]],<ref name="thesource">{{cite web|title=THE SOURCE MAGAZINE: Top Up & Coming Female Rapper Releases Her Latest Project|url=http://www.thesource.com/articles/235038/}}</ref> [[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]],<ref>{{cite web|title=XXL: Surviving The Times: Erick Sermon Talks About New Mixtape, Digital Label & Reviving Skills|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/features/2012/05/surviving-the-times-erick-sermon-talks-about-new-mixtape-digital-label-reviving-skills/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SHAHEEM REID: 5 STAR REVIEW FROM XXL'S EDITOR-AT-LARGE SHAHEEM REID & @TEAMSHAHEEM|url=http://3dnatee.com/main/?p=1340}}</ref> The Fader Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|title=THE FADER MAGAZINE: Features 3D Na'Tee - Lil Kim|url=http://www.thefader.com/index.php?s=na%27tee&submit.x=0&submit.y=0&submit=Go}}</ref> RapRadar<ref>{{cite web|title=RAPRADAR: RapRadar Search Features|url=http://rapradar.com/?s=3D+na%27tee&x=0&y=0}}</ref> and RapRehab.<ref>{{cite web|title=RAPREHAB: RapRehab's Featured Artist|url=http://raprehab.com/2012/08/3d-natee-new-orleans/}}</ref> She has also received attention from Louisiana newspapers and music magazines.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE SMOKING SECTION: 3D Na'Tee is Back and we have been invited to her Coronation|url=http://smokingsection.uproxx.com/TSS/2012/07/3d-natee-the-coronation-mixtape}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NOLA.COM: 4X Nola HipHop Award Winner 3D Na'Tee Raises The Bar Again By Being The First Native HipHop Artist With A Mobile App|url=http://www.nola.com/music/index.ssf/2011/09/industry_influence_celebrates.html}}</ref>
==Early life== In her middle school years, 3D Na'Tee honed her skills by what is called in New Orleans, ribbin' (rib - ing). Most people know this as "Playing the Dozens". Someone would start a beat by beating on a lunch room table or a garbage can, and off she went, lyrically attacking someone who was bold enough to test her skill. The rhymes were mostly about what they were wearing, how lame they were, or silly they looked.
In 1999, she began recording with local label called '''Clientell Records'''. Over the next five years, she would record multiple mixtapes under the "Snypa Squad" and feature on other projects Clientell Records came out with. However, in 2006, a year after [[Hurricane Katrina]], Clientell Records dismantled and 3D Na'Tee, who had previously established herself as a battler rapper amongst the local rap scene in New Orleans, released her first mix tape project '''"3's Company Vol.1: The Rapper, The Hustler, the Diva"''' followed by '''Volume 2''' in 2007. After the release of her second project, she appeared on '''The Kush 2''' DVD which was produced by [[YMCMB]] president [[Mack Maine]]. The DVD featured other Cash Money/Young Money artist like [[Lil Wayne]], [[Nicki Minaj]], and [[Birdman (entertainer)|Birdman]] as well as [[Curren$y]] of [[Warner Bros. Records]]
==Career== After the local success of her first two releases and her critically acclaimed appearance on '''The Kush 2''', she released her third mix tape '''Heavy Is the head That Wears The Crown''' followed by a music video for a song she titled, '''Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner'''. That video piqued the interest of [[G-Unit Records]] affiliate and [[Shade 45]] [[Sirius Satellite Radio|Sirius XM]] radio host Nelson Gomez who invited her to [[New York City|New York]] for an interview on his XM show as well as on rapper [[50 Cent|50 Cents']] wildly popular ThisIs50.com website. Soon after, the talk of her third release also got her featured in HipHop Weekly Magazine by [[Benzino]], former co-owner of [[The Source Magazine]].<ref>{{cite web|title=3DNATEE.COM: BIO|url=http://3dnatee.com/main/?page_id=28}}</ref>
Because of video releases like Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner which spoofed many mainstream hip hop artists, 3D Na'Tee's music has been described as controversial and sometimes offensive.<ref>{{cite web|title=WOMEN OF HIPHOP: 3D Na'Tee Explains How HipHop Saved Her Life, Talks Female Rap, and More|url=http://thewomenofhiphop.com/2012/08/04/wohh-exclusive-3d-natee-explains-how-hip-hop-saved-her-lifetalks-female-rap-more/}}</ref> That song also shared the title of her for mix tape released in 2010.
'''Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner''' (The Mixtape) lead to 3D Na'Tee being nominated for a total of 5 Nola HipHop Awards by her in her home town at the NOLA Hiphop Awards.<ref>{{cite web|title=OFFBEAT MAGAZINE: Nola HipHop Awards Nominees Finalized|url=http://www.offbeat.com/2010/10/14/nola-underground-hip-hop-award-nominees-finalized/}}</ref> She won three awards (the most awards won by a single artist) for '''Lyricist of the Year''', '''Mixtape of the Year''', and '''Female Artist of the Year'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASHLEE NICOLE SPILLS: Winners of the 2010 HipHop Awards Announced|url=http://www.ashleenicolespills.com/2010/10/20/winners-of-the-2010-nola-underground-hip-hop-awards/}}</ref> The mixtape included collaborations from [[Curren$y]] (courtesy of Warner Bros. Records), '''Ebony Eyez''',<ref>{{cite web|title=STL TODAY: Ebony Eyez Returns With A Story 2 Tell|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/ebony-eyez-returns-with-a-story-to-tell/article_6a65d3ae-d2bb-11e1-985c-0019bb30f31a.html}}</ref> and '''Babs Bunny''' (formally of [[Sean Combs|Sean "Diddy" Combs]]) founded group, [[Da Band]].<ref>{{cite web|title=SYFFAL: Forming Da Band|url=http://www.syffal.com/making-the-band}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ALL MUSIC.COM: Da Band's Discography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/da-band-mn0000764981}}</ref>
In early 2011 3D Na'Tee was featured on [[MTV|MTV's]] SuckerFree Freestyle<ref>{{cite web|title=MTV: SUCKERFREE FREESTYLE: 3DNATEE|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/misc/651008/sucker-freestyle-3dnatee.jhtml}}</ref> hosted by [[DJ Envy]]. 3D Na'Tee and Syleena collaborated on a song called '''Go Head'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=RHAPSODY: Syleena Johnson|url=http://www.rhapsody.com/artist/syleena-johnson/album/chapter-v-underrated/track/go-head-feat-natee}}</ref>
July 27, 2011 3D Na'Tee released a video for '''Switch'''<ref>{{cite web|title=WORLDSTARHIPHOP: 3D Na'Tee's Switch|url=http://hp-www.worldstarhiphop.com/videos/video800.php?v=wshhd71614snrClf6d9H&set_size=1}}</ref> which she shot and edited herself. The song included several previously released instrumental versions of songs produced by super producer [[Timbaland]]. This video gained her a nomination for '''Director of the Year''' and an award for '''Video of the Year'''. Because of the momentum the Switch video gained the day of its release, Timbaland viewed it online and in less than 24 hours, flew 3D Na'Tee to [[The Hit Factory|Miami's Hit Factory Studio]] to work with her on her next project, The Coronation.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE FADER MAGAZINE: 3D Na'Tee - Lil Kim|url=http://www.thefader.com/2012/07/30/video-natee-lil-kim/#comments}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ONWAX MAGAZINE: Rapper 3D Na'Tee shoots 'Wild' video in New Orleans, produced by Lex Luger|url=http://onwaxmagazine.com/owm/index.php/rapper-3d-natee-shoots-wild-video-in-new-orleans-produced-by-lex-luger/}}</ref> After several months spent traveling with Timbaland and other artist signed to his label, a contract was presented to 3D Na'Tee to sign to Timbaland's production company [[Mosley Music Group|Mosely Music Group]] and to be managed by members of Timbaland's management team. 3D Na'Tee and Timbaland later announced via [[Twitter]] that she was no longer a part of Timbaland's company because she decided not to sign the contract presented. In a later interview, 3D Na'Tee explained that there was no ill feelings towards Timbaland and cited her reasons for not signing were strictly because of contractual clauses that could not be agreed upon.<ref>{{cite web|title=DJSMALLZ.COM: INTERVIEW: SOUTHERN SMOKE TV! 3D NA'TEE (@3DNATEE) SPEAKS ON TURNING DOWN RECORD DEAL WITH TIMBALAND|url=http://www.djsmallz.com/blog/2012/5/18/interview-southern-smoke-tv-3d-natee-3dnatee-speaks-on-turni.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=WOMEN OF HIPHOP: [WOHH EXCLUSIVE]!|url=http://thewomenofhiphop.com/2012/08/04/wohh-exclusive-3d-natee-explains-how-hip-hop-saved-her-lifetalks-female-rap-more/}}</ref>
Exactly two years after 3D Na'Tee's last mix tape release, she released her highly anticipated street album ''The Coronation'' which featured artists like [[Keri Hilson]], Young Fletcher, and Lyrica Anderson. The Coronation also featured production from Mizay Entertainment's [[Lex Luger (producer)|Lex Luger]], [[Maybach Music Group|Maybach Music Group's]] Yung Shun, Heartbeatz, Casa Di, Versive Manhattan, Serious Beats, Da Smokestarz, among others.
In August 2012 it was announced by DJ Skee, Sirius Satellite Radio Host, that the first release from The Coronation entitled '''NO LOVE''' produced by [[Maybach Music Group|MMG's]] '''Young Shun''' was the #9 most requested song in the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=SIRIUS XM: #9 Song in the Country|url=https://twitter.com/DontHateBeHated/status/235174781102747648}}</ref> The Coronation's second release, '''Lil Kim''' produced by '''Casa Di''' gained tons of recognition as well as it was featured on both [[The Source (magazine)|The Source]] and [[The Fader]] Magazines' websites.<ref name="thesource" /><ref>{{cite web|title=FADER MAGAZINE: 3D Na'Tee Releases Lil Kim|url=http://www.thefader.com/2012/07/30/video-natee-lil-kim/#comments}}</ref> Lil Kim was a cautionary tale of a young girl with an absentee father who, because of her father's absence, unfortunately grew up and "fell in love" too fast. The song and its video (directed by Charley Mac), gained a lot of attention from tons of hiphop artist like [[Trina]], [[Missy Elliott]],<ref>{{cite web|title=WEBSTAGRAM: Trina Talks to 3D Na'Tee about 'Lil Kim|url=http://web.stagram.com/p/251601262639516075_14212753}}</ref> and Grammy Award Winning [[Chamillionaire]],<ref>{{cite web|title=BIG DOOR: Chamillionaire|url=http://www.bigdoor.com/company/press/grammy-award-winning-artist-and-bigdoor-ceo-to-speak-at-gamification-summit/}}</ref> who featured 3D Na'Tee's video on his famed social site [https://web.archive.org/web/20120802044043/http://www.chamillionaire.com/videos/play/608 www.chamillionaire.com].

{{Infobox musical artist | name = 3LAU | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | image =3LAU_at_his_F_Cancer_Benefit_in_Atlanta,_February_2018.jpg | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = 3LAU at his F Cancer Benefit in Atlanta, February 2018. | birth_name = Justin David Blau | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|01|09}} | birth_place = [[Syosset]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | origin = [[Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] | genre = {{hlist|[[Progressive house]], [[electro house]], [[deep house]], [[Synthwave (2000s genre)|synthwave]]{{cite web|last=Bein | first=Kat |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7957643/3lau-new-song-star-crossed |title=3LAU Rides the Synthwaves on 'Star Crossed' Ballad: Listen |website=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |accessdate=2018-01-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180104045651/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7957643/3lau-new-song-star-crossed |archivedate=2018-01-04 }}}} | occupation = {{hlist|[[Disc jockey|DJ]]|[[Record producer|producer]]}} | instrument = {{hlist|[[Synthesizer]]|[[DJ mixer|mixer]]|[[piano]]|[[guitar]]|[[Singing|vocals]]}} | years_active = 2011–present | label = {{hlist|[[Revealed Recordings|Revealed]]|[[Strictly Rhythm]]|[[Island Records|Island]]|[[Musical Freedom]]|[[Dim Mak Records|Dim Mak]]|BLUME}} | associated_acts = [[Heather Bright|Bright Lights]] | website = {{url|3lau.com/music}} }} '''Justin David Blau''' (born January 9, 1991), better known by his stage name '''3LAU''' (pronounced "Blau"), is an American DJ and [[electronic dance music]] producer. Based in [[Las Vegas]], he has released three mixtapes since 2011 and several singles, and has performed at festivals such as [[Electric Zoo]] in New York and EDC Vegas. In 2014 he released the track "Vikings" with Botnek on [[Dim Mak Records]]. ==Early life== Justin David Blau was born in [[Syosset]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States on {{birth date and age|1991|01|09}}. Blau grew up around an artistic family, and was soon playing piano, playing guitar and singing. At thirteen, he moved with his family to [[Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]], where he spent the rest of his youth. He attended [[The Meadows School]] for high school and [[Washington University in St. Louis]] for college. == Background == Much of 3LAU's music incorporates [[electro house]], [[dubstep]], [[deep house]], and [[progressive house]]. He is known for his melodic take on dance music and live sets that incorporate [[sampling (music)|sampling]]. He is also known for using [[Ableton]]. ==Music career== ===2011–12: First releases=== In 2011, at the age of 20, he vacationed in Sweden, where he discovered electronic dance music. After returning to college he started producing mashups, "mainly because [he] didn't think anyone was doing a good job." He soon began mixing under the professional name 3LAU, and by June of that year was uploading mashups to YouTube. 3LAU gained recognition in the [[electronic music]] world in 2011 with his two bootlegs, "Girls Who Save the World" and "All Night Long". He also won a remix competition for his remix of [[Tiesto]]'s "Work Hard, Play Hard". Before 2012, 3LAU spent his days studying at [[Washington University in St. Louis]] and DJing at night. He has had remixes charts in the top 10 on both [[Beatport]] and [[Hype Machine]]. ===2012–15: Singles, touring=== In 2012, he focused on DJing and launched his 3LAU Your Mind tour. That same year, he released his second bootleg album, ''Dance Floor Filth''. In 2012, the ''[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]'' described him as "one of America's fastest-rising DJ-producers." In 2012 he released ''Dance Floor Filth 2'', an album featuring his production. In late 2013, he went on a short tour with Carnage called the Night Riot tour. Wrote Jonah Ollman of ''Sound of Boston'' about 3LAU's live performances in late 2013, "A nice balance of mashups, electro-house, poppy vocal samples, and a 90’s throwback here and there keep the young 20-something crowd going and constantly entertained." In the summer of 2015, 3LAU did his first European tour visiting Barcelona, Germany and Ibiza. Later that fall, he went on his first Asian tour which included Bangkok, Jakarta, Tokyo and more.{{Cite web|title = Tour|url = http://www.3lau.com/tour|website = Tour|access-date = 2016-01-11|language = en-US|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160117071736/http://www.3lau.com/tour|archive-date = 2016-01-17|dead-url = yes|df = }} ===2018: ''Ultraviolet, OMF''=== On 16 February 2018, 3LAU released his debut album ''Ultraviolet'' on label "BLUME" featuring singles "Touch," "On My Own", "Walk Away" and "Star Crossed". The album features collaborations with Carly Paige, Nevve, [[Emma Hewitt]], [[Max Schneider]], [[Said the Sky]], and Neonheart. The album hit #1 on iTunes' Electronic Chart, as did lead single "Touch." {{cite web|title=C'est Prune:3LAU |url=https://www.prunemagazine.com/single-post/2018/03/27/Cest-Prune-3LAU |date=March 2018 |website=Prune Magazine |accessdate=2018-07-10 }}{{cite web|title=3LAU Reveals Tracklist and Features for Debut Album ‘Ultraviolet’ Coming Soon |first=Karlie |last=Powell |url=http://www.youredm.com/2017/12/30/3lau-reveals-tracklist-features-debut-album-ultraviolet-coming-soon/ |date=2017-12-30 |website=Your EDM |accessdate=2018-02-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171231022419/http://www.youredm.com/2017/12/30/3lau-reveals-tracklist-features-debut-album-ultraviolet-coming-soon/ |archivedate=2017-12-31 }} On 21 June 2018, 3LAU announced the launch of OMF (Our Music Festival), the first blockchain-powered music festival. The festival will be held on 20 October 2018 in San Francisco and will be headlined by [[Zedd]].{{cite web|title=3LAU Is Helping Launch The First Blockchain-Powered Music Festival |first=Natalie |last=Robehmed |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/natalierobehmed/2018/06/21/3lau-is-launching-the-first-blockchain-powered-music-festival/#1704d0b1fed5 |date=2018-06-21 |website=Forbes |accessdate=2018-07-10 }} == Philanthropy == In 2016, 3LAU launched the record label Blume, the first not-for-profit dance music label.{{Cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7318938/3lau-blume-charity-label-exclusive-dance|title=3LAU Launches Charity Label BLUME, Aims to Raise $100k in 2016:Exclusive |website=Billboard|access-date=2018-07-10}} Profits from all songs released on Blume are dedicated to charity. 3LAU has raised over $200,000 for non-profit Pencils of Promise.{{Cite web|url=https://fundraise.pencilsofpromise.org/fundraise?fcid=195142|title=3LAU x PoP - 3LAU x PoP's fundraising page for Pencils of Promise|website=Classy.org|access-date=2016-01-11}} In 2013, 3LAU announced he had built his first school with the non-profit and in 2018 another school was completed in Guatemala.{{Cite web|url=http://www.edmsauce.com/2013/01/24/first-school-built-with-3laus-pencils-of-promise-fundraiser/|title=First School Built with 3LAU's Pencils of Promise Fundraiser|website=EDM Sauce|access-date=2016-01-11}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Details ! scope="col" colspan="2"| Peak chart positions |- ! scope="col" style="width:2.5em;font-size:90%;"| [[Dance/Electronic Albums|iTunes

Buddy Austin |height = {{height|ft=6|in=0}}{{cite news|title=Statistics for Professional wrestlers|work=PWI Presents: 2007 Wrestling Almanak and book of facts|publisher=Kappa Publications|id=2007 Edition|page=38}} |weight = {{convert|256|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1977|5|22|mf=y}} |death_date = |alma_mater = [[University of Windsor]] |birth_place = [[Placentia, Newfoundland and Labrador|Placentia]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]]. [[Canada]] |resides = [[Dunnville, Ontario]], Canada |billed = [[Niagara Falls, Ontario]] |trainer = [[Scott D'Amore]] |debut = 2001 |retired = }} '''Alastair Charles Ralphs''' (born May 22, 1977) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] and former [[Bodybuilding|bodybuilder]], better known by his [[ring name]], '''A-1''' (alternatively spelled '''A1''' or '''A-One'''). He is best known for his appearances with [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] (TNA) from 2004 to 2007 as part of [[Team Canada (TNA)|Team Canada]]. ==Early life== Ralphs was born in [[Placentia Bay]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]], and relocated to [[Dunnville, Ontario|Dunnville]], [[Ontario]] at the age of five. He later moved to [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]], [[Ontario]] to attend the [[University of Windsor]]. ==Professional wrestling career== ===Border City Wrestling (2001–2005)=== Alastair Ralphs was trained by [[Scott D'Amore]] in the Can-Am Wrestling School, and debuted in D'Amore's [[Border City Wrestling]] promotion in 2001. After spending three years as an [[job (professional wrestling)|undercard talent]], Ralphs became A-1, a cocky, arrogant [[heel (professional wrestling)|heel]], forming an alliance with [[Joseph Dorgan|Johnny Swinger]]. He defeated [[D'Lo Brown]] for the BCW Heavyweight Championship on December 12, 2004, in [[Belleville, Michigan]] at "[[A Night of Appreciation for Sabu]]". On January 23, 2005, at New Year's Revolution, Ralphs interrupted the Hall of Fame induction ceremony, complaining that he was being overshadowed by older wrestlers. Scott D'Amore responded with a jibe aimed at Ralph's previous career as a [[Bodybuilding|bodybuilder]], leading to a brawl between Ralphs and D'Amore. Following a distraction from Jade, A-1 was able to powerbomb D'Amore through a table. Ralphs went on to retain the heavyweight title in a match with [[Abyss (wrestler)|Abyss]], using Abyss's own chain to knock him unconscious. Ralphs lost the BCW Heavyweight Championship to [[Bobby Roode]] on July 22, 2005. In the course of his reign as champion he faced well-known veterans such as [[Jim Neidhart]] and [[King Kong Bundy]]. ===Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (2004–2007)=== On July 16, 2004, Ralphs appeared in [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]], losing to [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]]. He reappeared on March 13, 2005 as a member of [[Team Canada (TNA)|Team Canada]], replacing the injured [[Johnny Devine]] at [[Destination X (2005)|Destination X 2005]] and teaming with Bobby Roode, [[Eric Young (wrestler)|Eric Young]] and [[Petey Williams]] to face [[Chris Harris (wrestler)|Chris Harris]], [[James Storm]], [[Brian Gerard James|B.G. James]] and [[Konnan]]. He wrestled on [[TNA Impact!]] throughout April and May 2005, [[tag team|teaming]] with other members of Team Canada or accompanying them to the ring. At [[TNA Hard Justice|Hard Justice]] on May 15, Ralphs took part in the [[Gauntlet for the Gold]]. He entered at number six and was eliminated by [[Monty Sopp|The Outlaw]] and B.G. James. On the May 11, 2006, episode of ''[[TNA Impact!]]'', [[Larry Zbyszko]] asked Team Canada coach [[Scott D'Amore]] for assistance in his feud with [[Raven (wrestler)|Raven]]. D'Amore eventually agreed to help Zbyszko rid TNA of Raven, and nominated A-1 to face Raven in a match at [[TNA Sacrifice#2006|TNA Sacrifice 2006]] in May 2006, a match that A-1 lost. On the June 29, 2006, episode of ''Impact!'', TNA Management Director [[Jim Cornette]] disbanded Team Canada. A-1 soon began wrestling sporadically, facing Ron Killings in the pre-show of the Hard Justice pay-per-view and against Eric Young at the No Surrender pay-per-view, losing both times. He also took part in the Kevin Nash Open Invitational X-Division Gauntlet Battle Royal at Bound For Glory, despite not being a part of the X-Division. He was eliminated by both [[Matt Bentley|Maverick Matt]] and [[Frankie Kazarian|Kazarian]]. A-1 was released by TNA in February 2007. ===Independent circuit (2007–present)=== Since leaving TNA, A-1 has wrestled on the independent circuit in Canada and the United States. At [[Impact One Night Only]]: Canadian Clash in February 2018, A-1 returned to [[Impact Wrestling]] for the first time in over 11 years, unsuccessfully challenging [[Eli Drake]] for the [[Impact Global Championship]]. He returned to Impact Wrestling once again at the following month's One Night Only: March Breakdown PPV, where he teamed with [[Allie (wrestler)|Allie]] in a victory over [[Braxton Sutter]] and KC Spinelli. He is also currently a member of the [[Border City Wrestling]] roster. ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[Border City Wrestling]]''' **[[BCW Can-Am Heavyweight Championship]] ([[BCW Can-Am Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/other/2004-12.html | title=Independent Wrestling Results – December 2004 | accessdate=2008-07-05|publisher=onlineworldofwrestling.com}} *'''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''' **PWI ranked him #'''253''' of the top 500 singles wrestlers in the [[Pro Wrestling Illustrated#PWI 500|PWI 500]] in 2007http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=1841&page=12 ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|2693399|A-1}} *[http://www.accelerator3359.com/Wrestling/bios/a1.html A-1 at Accelerator3359.com] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070318074502/http://www.tnawrestling.com/fullnews.php?home=255 Interview conducted by Bill Banks] {{BCW Can-Am Heavyweight Championship}} {{DEFAULTSORT:A-1}} [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Canadian bodybuilders]] [[Category:Canadian male professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Placentia, Newfoundland and Labrador]] [[Category:Professional wrestlers from Newfoundland and Labrador]]

page.title: A Dialogue on Personal Identity and Immortality

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = | name = 阿鸽; Hanyu Pinyin: Ā Gē | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1948}} | birth_place = [[Liangping County|Liangshan]], [[Sichuan]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Chinese | field = art | training = [[China Artists Association]] | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = | elected = | spouse = Xu Kuang | website = http://age.artron.net/ }} '''A Ge''' ([[Simplified Chinese]]: 阿鸽; [[Hanyu Pinyin]]: Ā Gē) (born 1948) is a [[China|Chinese]] print artist from [[Liangping County|Liangshan]] in [[Sichuan]] Province and is a member of the [[Yi people]] ethnic minority. ==Life== Per government policy towards ethnic minorities, A Ge was recruited at age twelve to attend the [[Sichuan Fine Arts Institute]] and was encouraged to create art to publicize Yi minority culture and help development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://age.artron.net/about|title=阿鸽艺术家介绍-阿鸽官方网站-雅昌艺术家网|website=age.artron.net|access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref>
In 1964 she graduated from the national minority class at the Sichuan branch of the [[China Artists Association]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Contemporary Chinese Women Painters | author=Shi, Ling | year=1998 | publisher=Foreign Languages Press | pages=199–201 | isbn=978-7-119-00724-3}}</ref> She is married to [[Xu Kuang]].
== Career == A Ge is a Grade 1 National Artist, a member of the [[China Artists Association]] and the Chinese Engravers Association, and is chairman of the Sichuan Artists Association.<ref name="Artists">{{cite book | title=Modern Chinese Artists | author=Sullivan, Michael | year=2006 | publisher=University of California Press | page=3 | isbn=978-0-520-24449-8}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://baike.baidu.com/item/阿鸽|title=Baidu|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Her works have been collected by the [[British Museum]] in London.<ref>{{cite book | title=The Printed Image in China | author=von Spee, Clarissa | year=2010 | publisher=British Museum Press | page=171 | isbn=978-0-7141-2460-5}}</ref>
== Works == Selected works:
* 《阿鸽版画》 (''Prints of A Ge'') * 《四川少数民族画家画库·阿鸽》 (''Sichuan Minority Artists Gallery - A Ge'', 1995) * [http://age.artron.net/book_pubinfo_112017 《阿鸽作品集》](''Collection of A Ge's Artwork - A Ge, 2010 Sichuan Art Publishers'')
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://baike.baidu.com/view/924172.htm1.htm Baike webpage for A Ge (Chinese)] *[http://age.artron.net/ Official website for A Ge (Chinese)]
[http://age.artron.net/ {{authority control}}]
{{DEFAULTSORT:A, Ge}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century Chinese artists]] [[Category:20th-century women artists]] [[Category:Artists from Sichuan]] [[Category:People from Liangshan]]
{{China-artist-stub}}
