Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/79.166.55.37|79.166.55.37]] ([[User talk:79.166.55.37|talk]]): nonconstructive edits ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.1)
revision.text:
[[File:Spermathek Acanthoscurria geniculata.jpg|thumb|Spermatheca of ''[[Acanthoscurria geniculata]]'' (Brazilian Giant White Knee Tarantula)]] [[File:Parasite170028-fig20 Illustrated guide of Phlebotominae (Diptera, Psychodidae).png|thumb|Variety of the structure of spermathecae in [[Phlebotominae]] (Diptera, Psychodidae)]]
The '''spermatheca''' (pronounced {{IPAc-en|s|p|ɚ|m|ə|ˈ|θ|iː|k|ə}} plural: '''spermathecae''' {{IPAc-en|s|p|ɚ|m|ə|ˈ|θ|iː|s|iː}}), also called '''receptaculum seminis''' (plural: '''receptacula seminis'''), is an [[organ (biology)|organ]] of the female reproductive tract in [[insect]]s, e.g. [[bee]]s,<ref>Tales V. Pascini, and Gustavo F. Martins. 2017. "The insect spermatheca: an overview". ZOOLOGY https://doi.org/10.1016/j.zool.2016.12.001</ref> some [[mollusc]]s, [[oligochaeta]] worms and certain other [[invertebrate]]s and [[vertebrate]]s.<ref>David M. Sever, Cynthia K. Tait, Lowell V. Diller, and Laura Burkholder. 2004. ''Ultrastructure of the Annual Cycle of Female Sperm Storage in Spermathecae of the Torrent Salamander'' [[Rhyacotriton variegatus]] ''(Amphibia: Rhyacotritonidae)''. JOURNAL OF MORPHOLOGY 261:1–17</ref> Its purpose is to receive and [[female sperm storage|store sperm]] from the male or, in the case of [[hermaphrodites]], the male component of the body. Spermathecae can sometimes be the site of [[fertilisation|fertilization]] when the [[oocyte]]s are sufficiently developed.<ref>Jan A. Pechenick. Biology of the Invertebrates. New York: McGraw Hill, 2005</ref>
Some species of animal have multiple spermathecae. For example, certain species of earthworms have four pairs of spermathecae—one pair each in the 6th, 7th, 8th, and 9th segments. The spermathecae receive and store the spermatozoa of another earthworm during copulation.<ref>Jan A. Pechenik. Biology of the Invertebrates. New York: McGraw Hill, 2010, pg. 322</ref> They are lined with [[epithelium]] and are variable in shape: some are thin, heavily coiled tubes, while others are vague outpocketings from the main reproductive tract. It is one of the many variations in sexual reproduction.
The nematode ''[[Caenorhabditis elegans]]'' has two spermathecae, one at the end of each gonad.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = On the control of oocyte meiotic maturation and ovulation in Caenorhabditis elegans.|date = |journal = Dev. Biol.|doi = 10.1006/dbio.1998.9109|pmid = 9882501|access-date = |volume=205 |year=1999 |pages=111–28 | last1 = McCarter | first1 = J | last2 = Bartlett | first2 = B | last3 = Dang | first3 = T | last4 = Schedl | first4 = T}}</ref> The ''C. elegans'' spermatheca is made up of 24 smooth muscle-like cells that form a stretchable tubular structure.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wormatlas.org/hermaphrodite/somatic%20gonad/Images/somaticfig8leg.htm|title = WormAtlas|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> [[Microfilament|Actin filaments]] line the spermatheca in a circumferential manner. The ''C. elegans'' spermatheca is used as a model to study [[mechanotransduction]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = FLN-1/Filamin is required for maintenance of actin and exit of fertilized oocytes from the spermatheca in C. elegans|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012160610009899|journal = Developmental Biology|date = 2010-11-15|pmc = 2957521|pmid = 20707996|pages = 247–257|volume = 347|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.ydbio.2010.08.005|first = Ismar|last = Kovacevic|first2 = Erin J.|last2 = Cram}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Transient Membrane Localization of SPV-1 Drives Cyclical Actomyosin Contractions in the C. elegans Spermatheca|url = http://www.cell.com/article/S0960982214014948/abstract|journal = Current Biology|issn = 0960-9822|pmid = 25532891|pages = 141–151|volume = 25|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.cub.2014.11.033|first = Pei Yi|last = Tan|first2 = Ronen|last2 = Zaidel-Bar|year=2015}}</ref>
An [[beekeeping|apiculturist]] may examine the spermatheca of a dead [[queen bee]] to find out whether it had received [[sperm]] from a male.<ref name="glenn">{{cite web | url=http://www.glenn-apiaries.com/sperm.html | title=Diagnosis of failing queens by inspecting the spermatheca | accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> In many species of stingless bees, especially [[Melipona bicolor]], the [[Queen bee|queen]] lays her eggs during the provisioning and oviposition process and the spermatheca fertilizes the egg as it passes along the [[oviduct]]. The [[Haplodiploidy|haplo-diploid]] system of [[Sex-determination system|sex determination]] makes it possible for the queen to choose the sex of the egg.<ref name=Koedam>Koedam, D., et al. "The Behaviour Of Laying Workers And The Morphology And Viability Of Their Eggs In Melipona Bicolor Bicolor." Physiological Entomology 26.3 (2001): 254-259. Academic Search Premier. Web. 26 Sept. 2015.</ref>
== See also == * [[Cyphopod]]s, sperm receptacles in female millipedes * [[Female sperm storage]] * [[Reproductive system of gastropods]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Animal reproductive system]] [[Category:Sexual anatomy]] [[Category:Animal anatomy]] [[Category:Reproduction]]

'''Strategies for Engineered Negligible Senescence''' ('''SENS''') is the term coined by British biogerontologist [[Aubrey de Grey]] for the diverse range of [[Regenerative medicine|regenerative medical]] therapies, either planned or currently in development,<ref>Research Themes (February 4, 2013). "http://www.sens.org/research/introduction-to-sens-research". ''SENS Research Foundation website''</ref> for the periodical repair of all age-related damage to human tissue with the ultimate purpose of maintaining a state of [[negligible senescence]] in the patient, thereby postponing [[age-associated disease]] for as long as the therapies are reapplied.<ref name=EndingAging>de Grey, Aubrey; Rae, Michael (September 2007). ''Ending Aging: The Rejuvenation Breakthroughs that Could Reverse Human Aging in Our Lifetime''. New York, NY: St. Martin's Press, 416 pp. {{ISBN|0-312-36706-6}}.</ref>
The term "[[negligible senescence]]" was first used in the early 1990s by professor [[Caleb Finch]] to describe organisms such as [[lobsters]] and [[hydra (genus)|hydra]]s, which do not show symptoms of aging. The term "engineered negligible senescence" first appeared in print in [[Aubrey de Grey]]'s 1999 book ''The Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging'',<ref name="isbn1587061554">de Grey, Aubrey (November 2003). ''The Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging.'' Austin, Texas: Landes Bioscience. {{ISBN|1-58706-155-4}}.</ref> and was later prefaced with the term "strategies" in the article ''Time to Talk SENS: Critiquing the Immutability of Human Aging''<ref name="pmid11976218">de Grey AD, Ames BN, Andersen JK, Bartke A, Campisi J, Heward CB, McCarter RJ, Stock G (April 2002). "[http://www.sens.org/files/pdf/manu12.pdf Time to Talk SENS: Critiquing the Immutability of Human Aging]". ''Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences'' 959: 452–62. {{PMID|11976218}}.</ref> De Grey called SENS a "goal-directed rather than curiosity-driven"<ref>Bulkes, Nyssa (March 6, 2006). "[http://northernstar.info/city/anti-aging-research-breakthroughs-may-add-up-to-years-to/article_a4d2acd9-475d-5e12-a81c-77011f9c65ad.html Anti-aging research breakthroughs may add up to 25 years to life]". ''The Northern Star''. Northern Illinois University (DeKalb, USA).</ref> approach to the science of aging, and "an effort to expand regenerative medicine into the territory of aging".<ref>. "[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aubrey-de-grey-phd/age-related-diseases_b_985019.html Age-Related Diseases: Medicine's Final Adversary?]". ''Huffington Post Healthy Living''.</ref> To this end, SENS identifies seven categories of aging "damage" and a specific regenerative medical proposal for treating each.
While many [[Biogerontology|biogerontologists]] find it "worthy of discussion"<ref name=PontinJuly112006>Pontin, Jason (July 11, 2006). "[http://www2.technologyreview.com/sens/ Is Defeating Aging Only A Dream?]". ''Technology Review''.</ref><ref name="Invincible Man">Garreau, Joel (October 31, 2007). "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/30/AR2007103002222.html?hpid=features1&hpv=nationalThe Invincible Man]". ''Washington Post''.</ref> and SENS conferences feature important research in the field,<ref name="SENS4Abstracts">Fourth SENS Conference (2009). [http://www.sens.org/index.php?pagename=sens4_abstracts Over 140 Accepted Abstracts]. Cambridge, England, September 3–7th, 2009.</ref><ref>Kristen Fortney (2009). [http://www.fightaging.org/archives/2009/09/sens4-conference-coverage-from-ouroboros.php SENS4 Conference Coverage From Ouroboros]. FightAging.org, September 4, 2009.</ref> some contend that the ultimate goals of de Grey's programme are too speculative given the current state of technology, referring to it as "fantasy rather than science".<ref name=EMBOSENS>{{cite journal|author=Warner H|author2=Anderson J|author3=Austad S |title=Science fact and the SENS agenda. What can we reasonably expect from ageing research?|journal=EMBO Reports |volume=6 |issue=11 |pages=1006–8 |date=November 2005 |pmid=16264422 |pmc=1371037 |doi=10.1038/sj.embor.7400555|author4=et al.|displayauthors=1}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite journal |author=Holliday R |title=The extreme arrogance of anti-aging medicine |journal=Biogerontology |volume=10 |issue=2 |pages=223–8 |date=April 2009 |pmid=18726707 |doi=10.1007/s10522-008-9170-6}}</ref>
==Framework==
[[File:Aging treatment approaches.jpg|right|thumb|300px|The arrows with flat heads are a notation meaning "inhibits," used in the literature of gene expression and gene regulation.]]
The ultimate objective of SENS is the eventual elimination of age-related diseases and infirmity by repeatedly reducing the state of senescence in the organism. The SENS project consists in implementing a series of periodic medical interventions designed to repair, prevent or render irrelevant all the types of molecular and cellular damage that cause age-related pathology and degeneration, in order to avoid debilitation and death from age-related causes.<ref name=EndingAging/>
De Grey defines aging as "the set of accumulated side effects from metabolism that eventually kills us", and, more specifically, as follows: "a collection of cumulative changes to the [[molecule|molecular]] and [[cell (biology)|cellular]] structure of an [[adult]] [[organism]], which result in essential [[metabolism|metabolic]] processes, but which also, once they progress far enough, increasingly disrupt metabolism, resulting in [[pathology]] and death."<ref name="pmid12844502">de Grey, Aubrey (January 8, 2003). "[http://www.sens.org/files/pdf/manu16.pdf An engineer's approach to the development of real anti-aging medicine]". ''Sci Aging Knowledge Environ''. 2003 (1): VP1. {{doi|10.1126/sageke.2003.1.vp1}}. {{PMID|12844502}}.</ref> He adds: "[[geriatrics]] is the attempt to stop damage from causing pathology; traditional [[gerontology]] is the attempt to stop [[metabolism]] from causing damage; and the SENS (engineering) approach is to eliminate the damage periodically, so keeping its abundance below the level that causes any pathology." The SENS approach to biomedical [[gerontology]] is thus distinctive because of its emphasis on tissue rejuvenation rather than attempting to slow the aging process.
By enumerating the various differences between young and old tissue identified by the science of [[biogerontology]], a 'damage' report was drawn, which in turn formed the basis of the SENS strategy. The results fell into seven main categories of 'damage', seven alterations whose reversal would constitute [[negligible senescence]]:
# cell loss or atrophy (without replacement),<ref name="pmid11976218"/><ref name="pmid12844502"/><ref>de Grey, Aubrey (2005). "[http://www.sens.org/files/sens/FHT-PP.pdf A strategy for postponing aging indefinitely]". ''Stud Health Technol Inform.'' 118: 209–19. {{PMID|16301780}}.</ref> # [[oncology|oncogenic]] [[cell nucleus|nuclear]] [[mutation]]s and [[epimutation]]s,<ref>de Grey AD, Campbell FC, Dokal I, Fairbairn LJ, Graham GJ, Jahoda CA, Porterg AC (June 2004). [http://www.sens.org/files/sens/WILT.pdf Total deletion of ''in vivo'' telomere elongation capacity: an ambitious but possibly ultimate cure for all age-related human cancers]. ''Ann N Y Acad Sci''. 1019: 147–70. {{doi|10.1196/annals.1297.026}}. {{PMID|15247008}}.</ref><ref>de Grey, Aubrey (September 1, 2005). "[http://www.sens.org/files/sens/WILT-FBS.pdf Whole-body interdiction of lengthening of telomeres: a proposal for cancer prevention]". ''Frontiers in Bioscience''. 10: 2420–29. {{PMID|15970505}}.</ref><ref name="pmid17588643">de Grey, Aubrey (July–August 2007). "[http://www.sens.org/files/sens/nucmutPP.pdf Protagonistic pleiotropy: Why cancer may be the only pathogenic effect of accumulating nuclear mutations and epimutations in aging]". ''Mech Ageing Dev''. 128 (7–8): 456–59. {{doi|10.1016/j.mad.2007.05.005}}. {{PMID|17588643}}.</ref> # cell [[senescence]] (Death-resistant cells),<ref name="pmid12556198">de Grey, Aubrey (February 2003). "[http://www.sens.org/files/sens/manu21.pdf Challenging but essential targets for genuine anti-ageing drugs]". ''Expert Opinion on Therapeutic Targets''. 7 (1): 1–5. {{doi|10.1517/14728222.7.1.1}}. {{PMID|12556198}}.</ref><ref name="pmid17100587">de Grey, Aubrey (November 2006). "[http://www.sens.org/files/sens/excellPP.pdf Foreseeable pharmaceutical repair of age-related extracellular damage]". ''Curr Drug Targets''. 7 (11): 1469–77. {{ISSN|1389-4501}}. {{PMID|17100587}}.</ref> # [[mitochondria]]l mutations,<ref>de Grey, Aubrey (Fall 2004). "[http://www.sens.org/files/sens/polg-PP.pdf Mitochondrial Mutations in Mammalian Aging: An Over-Hasty About-Turn?]" ''Rejuvenation Res''. 7 (3): 171–4. {{doi|10.1089/rej.2004.7.171}}. {{PMID|15588517}}.</ref><ref>de Grey, Aubrey (September 2000). "[http://www.sens.org/files/sens/allo.pdf Mitochondrial gene therapy: an arena for the biomedical use of inteins]". ''Trends Biotechnol''. 18 (9): 394–99. {{doi|10.1016/S0167-7799(00)01476-1}}". {{PMID|10942964}}.</ref> # Intracellular junk or junk inside cells ([[lysosome|lysosomal]] aggregates),<ref>de Grey, Aubrey (November 2002). "[http://www.sens.org/files/sens/manu15.pdf Bioremediation meets biomedicine: therapeutic translation of microbial catabolism to the lysosome]". ''Trends Biotechnol''. 20 (11): 452–5. {{doi|10.1016/S0167-7799(02)02062-0}}. {{PMID|12413818}}.</ref><ref>de Grey AD, Alvarez PJJ, Brady RO, Cuervo AM, Jerome WG, McCarty PL, Nixon RA, Rittmann BE, Sparrow JR (August 2005). "[http://www.sens.org/files/sens/medbioremPP.pdf Medical bioremediation: prospects for the application of microbial catabolic diversity to aging and several major age-related diseases]". ''Ageing Research Reviews''. 4 (3): 315–38. {{doi|10.1016/j.arr.2005.03.008}}. {{PMID|16040282}}.</ref> # extracellular junk or junk outside cells (extracellular aggregates),<ref name="pmid12556198"/><ref name="pmid17100587"/> # random extracellular cross-linking.<ref name="pmid12556198"/><ref name="pmid17100587"/>
For each of these areas SENS offers at least one strategy, with a research and a clinical component. The clinical component is required because in some of the proposed therapies, feasibility has already been proven, but not completely applied and approved for human trials. These strategies do not presuppose that the underlying metabolic mechanisms of aging be fully understood, only that we take into account the form senescence takes as directly observable to science, and described in scientific literature..
==Types of aging damage and treatment schemes==
===Nuclear mutations/epimutations—OncoSENS=== These are changes to the nuclear DNA ([[nDNA]]), or to proteins which bind to the nDNA. Certain mutations can lead to [[cancer]].
This would need to be corrected in order to prevent or [[cure for cancer|cure cancer]]. SENS focuses on a strategy called "whole-body interdiction of lengthening [[telomere]]s" (WILT), which would be made possible by periodic [[regenerative medicine]] treatments.
===Mitochondrial mutations—MitoSENS===
[[Mitochondria]] are components in our [[cell (biology)|cells]] that are important for [[energy]] production. Because of the highly [[Oxidative stress|oxidative]] environment in mitochondria and their lack of the sophisticated repair systems, mitochondrial mutations are believed to be a major cause of progressive cellular degeneration.
This would be corrected by [[allotopic expression]]—copying the [[DNA]] for mitochondria completely within the cellular [[Cell nucleus|nucleus]], where it is better protected. De Grey argues that experimental evidence demonstrates that the operation is feasible, however, a 2003 study showed that some mitochondrial proteins are too [[hydrophobic]] to survive the transport from the cytoplasm to the mitochondria.<ref>Oca-Cossio, J. et al., 2003. Limitations of Allotopic Expression of Mitochondrial Genes in Mammalian Cells. Genetics, 165(2), 707–720. </ref>
===Intracellular junk—LysoSENS=== {{tone|date=January 2018}} Our cells are constantly breaking down [[protein]]s and other molecules that are no longer useful or which can be harmful. Those molecules which can’t be digested accumulate as junk inside our cells, which is detected in the form of [[lipofuscin]] granules. [[Atherosclerosis]], [[macular degeneration]], [[liver spot]]s on the skin and all kinds of [[neurodegenerative disease]]s (such as [[Alzheimer's]] disease) are associated with this problem.
Junk inside cells might be removed by adding new [[enzymes]] to the cell's natural [[digestion]] organ, the [[lysosome]]. These enzymes would be taken from [[bacteria]], [[mold]]s and other organisms that are known to completely digest animal bodies.
===Extracellular junk—AmyloSENS===
Harmful junk protein can accumulate outside of our cells. Junk here means useless things accumulated by a body, but which cannot be digested or removed by its processes, such as the amyloid plaques characteristic of [[Alzheimer's disease]] and other [[amyloidosis|amyloidoses]].
Junk outside cells might be removed by enhanced [[phagocytosis]] (the normal process used by the immune system), and small drugs able to break chemical beta-bonds. The large junk in this class can be removed surgically.
===Cell loss and atrophy—RepleniSENS===
Some of the cells in our bodies cannot be replaced, or can be only replaced very slowly—more slowly than they die. This decrease in cell number affects some of the most important tissues of the body. Muscle cells are lost in [[skeletal muscle]]s and the heart, causing them to become frailer with age. Loss of neurons in the [[substantia nigra]] causes [[Parkinson's disease]], while loss of immune cells impairs the [[immune system]].
This can be partly corrected by therapies involving [[exercise]] and [[growth factor]]s, but [[stem cell therapy]], [[regenerative medicine]] and [[tissue engineering]] are almost certainly required for any more than just partial replacement of lost cells.
===Cell senescence—ApoptoSENS===
[[Cellular senescence#Cellular senescence|Senescence]] is a phenomenon where the cells are no longer able to divide, but also do not die and let others divide. They may also do other harmful things, like secreting proteins. Degeneration of [[joint]]s, immune senescence, accumulation of [[visceral fat]] and [[diabetes mellitus type 2|type 2 diabetes]] are caused by this. Cells sometimes enter a state of resistance to signals sent, as part of a process called [[apoptosis]], to instruct cells to destroy themselves.
Cells in this state could be eliminated by forcing them to apoptose (via [[suicide gene]]s, [[vaccine]]s, or recently discovered [[senolytics|senolytic agents]]), and healthy cells would multiply to replace them.
===Extracellular crosslinks—GlycoSENS===
Cells are held together by special linking proteins. When too many [[cross-links]] form between cells in a [[Biological tissue|tissue]], the tissue can lose its elasticity and cause problems including arteriosclerosis, presbyopia and weakened skin texture. These are chemical bonds between structures that are part of the body, but not within a [[Cell (biology)|cell]]. In senescent people many of these become brittle and weak.
SENS proposes to further develop small-molecular drugs and [[enzyme]]s to break links caused by sugar-bonding, known as [[advanced glycation endproduct]]s, and other common forms of chemical linking.
==Scientific controversy== While some fields mentioned as branches of SENS are broadly supported by the medical research community, e.g., [[stem cell research]] (RepleniSENS), [[Alzheimer's disease clinical research|anti-Alzheimers research]] (AmyloSENS) and [[oncogenomics]] (OncoSENS), the SENS programme as a whole has been a highly controversial proposal, with many critics arguing that the SENS agenda is fanciful and the highly complicated biomedical phenomena involved in the aging process contain too many unknowns for SENS to be fully implementable in the foreseeable future<ref name="pmid16264422" />. Cancer may well deserve special attention as an [[Aging-associated diseases|aging-associated disease]] (OncoSENS), but the SENS claim that nuclear DNA damage only matters for aging because of cancer has been challenged in the literature<ref>{{cite journal | author=Best, BP | title=Nuclear DNA damage as a direct cause of aging | journal=Rejuvenation Research | volume=12 | issue=3 | date=2009 | pages=199–208 | url=http://www.benbest.com/lifeext/Nuclear_DNA_in_Aging.pdf | format= [[PDF]] | doi = 10.1089/rej.2009.0847 | pmid=19594328 }}</ref> as well as by material in the article [[DNA damage theory of aging]].
In November 2005, 28 biogerontologists published a statement of criticism in ''[[EMBO Journal|EMBO Reports]]'', "Science fact and the SENS agenda: what can we reasonably expect from ageing research?,"<ref name="pmid16264422">Warner H ''et al.'' (November 2005). "Science fact and the SENS agenda. What can we reasonably expect from ageing research?". ''EMBO Reports''. 6 (11): 1006–1008. {{doi|10.1038/sj.embor.7400555}}. {{PMID|16264422}}.</ref> arguing "each one of the specific proposals that comprise the SENS agenda is, at our present stage of ignorance, exceptionally optimistic,"<ref name="pmid16264422"/> and that some of the specific proposals "will take decades of hard work [to be medically integrated], if [they] ever prove to be useful."<ref name="pmid16264422"/> The researchers argue that while there is "a rationale for thinking that we might eventually learn how to postpone human illnesses to an important degree,"<ref name="pmid16264422"/> increased basic research, rather than the goal-directed approach of SENS, is presently the scientifically appropriate goal. This article was written in response to a July 2005 ''EMBO Reports'' article previously published by de Grey<ref>de Grey, Aubrey (July 2005). "Resistance to debate on how to postpone ageing is delaying progress and costing lives". ''EMBO Reports''. 6 (S1): S49–S53. {{doi|10.1038/sj.embor.7400399}}. {{PMID|15995663}}.</ref> and a response from de Grey was published in the same November issue.<ref>de Grey, Aubrey (November 2005). "Like it or not, life-extension research extends beyond biogerontology". ''EMBO Reports''. 6 (11): 1000. {{doi|10.1038/sj.embor.7400565}}. {{PMID|16264420}}.</ref> De Grey summarizes these events in "The biogerontology research community's evolving view of SENS," published on the [[Methuselah Foundation]] website.<ref>de Grey, Aubrey. "[http://www.mfoundation.org/files/sens/Gandhi3.htm The biogerontology research community's evolving view of SENS]". Methuselah Foundation. Retrieved on July 1, 2008.</ref>
In 2012, [[Colin Blakemore]] criticised Aubrey de Grey, but not SENS specifically, in a debate hosted at the [[Oxford University]] Scientific Society.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
More recently, biogerontologist [[Marios Kyriazis]] has sharply criticised the clinical applicability of SENS<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kyriazis M |title=The impracticality of biomedical rejuvenation therapies: translational and pharmacological barriers |journal=Rejuvenation Research |volume=17 |issue=4 |pages=390–6 |year=2014 |pmid=25072550 |pmc=4142774 |doi=10.1089/rej.2014.1588 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kyriazis |first1=Marios |title=Translating laboratory anti-aging biotechnology into applied clinical practice: Problems and obstacles |journal=World Journal of Translational Medicine |volume=4 |issue=2 |year=2015 |pages=51–4 |doi=10.5528/wjtm.v4.i2.51}}</ref> claiming that such therapies, even if developed in the laboratory, would be practically unusable by the general public.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kyriazis M, Apostolides A |title=The Fallacy of the Longevity Elixir: Negligible Senescence May be Achieved, but Not by Using Something Physical |journal=Current Aging Science |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=227–34 |year=2015 |pmid=26135528 |url=http://www.eurekaselect.com/132663/article |doi=10.2174/1874609808666150702095803}}</ref> De Grey responded to one such criticism.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=de Grey AD |title=The practicality or otherwise of biomedical rejuvenation therapies: a response to Kyriazis |journal=Rejuvenation Research |volume=17 |issue=4 |pages=397–400 |year=2014 |pmid=25072964 |doi=10.1089/rej.2014.1599 }}</ref>
===''Technology Review'' controversy===
In February 2005, ''[[Technology Review]]'', which is owned by the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], published an article by [[Sherwin Nuland]], a Clinical Professor of Surgery at [[Yale University]] and the author of "How We Die",<ref>Nuland, Sherwin (1994). ''How We Die: Reflections on Life's Final Chapter''. New York: Knopf Random House. {{ISBN|0-679-41461-4}}.</ref> that drew a skeptical portrait of SENS, at the time de Grey was a computer associate in the [https://web.archive.org/web/20100108033304/http://www.gen.cam.ac.uk/Research/flybase.htm Flybase Facility] of the [http://www.gen.cam.ac.uk/ Department of Genetics] at the [[University of Cambridge]]. The April 2005 issue of ''Technology Review'' contained a reply by Aubrey de Grey<ref>de Grey, Aubrey (April2005). "[http://www.technologyreview.com/read_article.aspx?id=14097&ch=infotech Aubrey de Grey Responds]", ''Technology Review''.</ref> and numerous comments from readers.<ref>TR Readers (April 2005). "[http://www.technologyreview.com/read_article.aspx?id=14310&ch=infotechReaders LETTERS: Our February cover story on Aubrey de Grey and antiaging science lives on]". ''Technology Review''.</ref>
During June 2005, [[David Gobel]], CEO and Co-founder of Methuselah Foundation offered Technology Review $20,000 to fund a prize competition to publicly clarify the viability of the SENS approach. In July 2005, Pontin announced a $20,000 prize, funded 50/50 by Methuselah Foundation and MIT Technology Review, open to any molecular biologist, with a record of publication in biogerontology, who could prove that the alleged benefits of SENS were "so wrong that it is unworthy of learned debate."<ref>Pontin, Jason (July 28, 2005). "[http://www.technologyreview.com/blog/pontin/14968/ The SENS Challenge]". ''Technology Review''.</ref> ''Technology Review'' received five submissions to its Challenge. In March 2006, ''Technology Review'' announced that it had chosen a panel of judges for the Challenge: [[Rodney Brooks]], [[Anita Goel]], [[Nathan Myhrvold]], [[Vikram Sheel Kumar]], and [[Craig Venter]].<ref>Pontin, Jason (March 14, 2006). "[http://www.technologyreview.com/Biotech/16593/ We've picked the judges for our biogerontology prize]". ''Technology Review''.</ref> Three of the five submissions met the terms of the prize competition. They were published by ''Technology Review'' on June 9, 2006. Accompanying the three submissions were rebuttals by de Grey, and counter-responses to de Grey's rebuttals. On July 11, 2006, ''Technology Review'' published the results of the SENS Challenge.<ref name="PontinJuly112006"/><ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20130606111748/http://www.mprize.com/index.php?pagename=newsdetaildisplay&ID=0104 SENS Withstands Three Challenges : $20,000 Remains Unclaimed]". Methuselah Foundation. Retrieved on July 1, 2008.</ref>
In the end, no one won the $20,000 prize. The judges felt that no submission met the criterion of the challenge and discredited SENS, although they unanimously agreed that one submission, by [[Preston Estep]] and his colleagues, was the most eloquent. [[Craig Venter]] succinctly expressed the prevailing opinion: "Estep et al. ... have not demonstrated that SENS is unworthy of discussion, but the proponents of SENS have not made a compelling case for it."<ref name="PontinJuly112006"/> Summarizing the judges' deliberations, Pontin wrote that SENS is "highly speculative" and that many of its proposals {{clarify|text=could not be reproduced with the scientific technology of that period.|date=April 2016}} Myhrvold described SENS as belonging to a kind of "antechamber of science" where they wait until technology and scientific knowledge advance to the point where it can be tested.<ref name="PontinJuly112006"/><ref name="Invincible Man"/> In a letter of dissent dated July 11, 2006 in Technology Review, Estep et al. criticized the ruling of the judges.
==Social and economic implications==
Of the roughly 150,000 people who die each day across the globe, about two thirds—100,000 per day—die of age-related causes.<ref name="doi10.2202/1941-6008.1011">{{cite journal | last = Aubrey D.N.J | first = de Grey | authorlink = Aubrey de Grey | title = Life Span Extension Research and Public Debate: Societal Considerations | journal = Studies in Ethics, Law, and Technology | volume = 1 | issue = 1, Article 5 | date = 2007 | url = http://www.sens.org/files/sens/ENHANCE-PP.pdf | format = PDF | doi = 10.2202/1941-6008.1011 | accessdate = March 20, 2009}}</ref> In industrialized nations, the proportion is much higher, reaching 90%.<ref name="doi10.2202/1941-6008.1011"/>
De Grey and other scientists in the general field have argued that the costs of a rapidly growing aging population will increase to the degree that the costs of an accelerated pace of aging research are easy to justify in terms of future costs avoided. Olshansky ''et al.'' 2006 argue, for example, that the total economic cost of [[Alzheimer's disease]] in the US alone will increase from $80–100 billion today to more than $1 trillion in 2050.<ref name=TheLongevityDividend>Olshansky, S. Jay; Perry, Daniel; Miller, Richard A.; Butler, Robert N. (March 2006). "[https://web.archive.org/web/20160110004616/http://www.edmontonagingsymposium.com/files/eas/Longevity_Dividend.pdf In Pursuit of the Longevity Dividend: What Should We Be Doing To Prepare for the Unprecedented Aging of Humanity?]". ''The Scientist''. 20 (3): 28–36.</ref> "Consider what is likely to happen if we don't [invest further in aging research]. Take, for instance, the impact of just one age-related disorder, Alzheimer disease (AD). For no other reason than the inevitable shifting demographics, the number of Americans stricken with AD will rise from 4 million today to as many as 16 million by midcentury. This means that more people in the United States will have AD by 2050 than the entire current population of the Netherlands. Globally, AD prevalence is expected to rise to 45 million by 2050, with three of every four patients with AD living in a developing nation. The US economic toll is currently $80–$100 billion, but by 2050 more than $1 trillion will be spent annually on AD and related dementias. The impact of this single disease will be catastrophic, and this is just one example."<ref name=TheLongevityDividend/>

There have been four SENS [[Round table|roundtables]] and six SENS [[Academic conference|conferences]] held.<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20081021070535/http://www.mprize.com/index.php?pagename=meetings Conferences]". Methuselah Foundation. Methuselah Foundation. Retrieved on July 1, 2008.</ref> and the last SENS roundtable was held in [[Bethesda, Maryland]] on July, 2004.<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20080523163019/http://www.mfoundation.org/meetings/roundtable4 SENS roundtable 4: Enhancing lysosomal catabolic function using microbial enzymes (July 26, 2004)]". Methuselah Foundation. Retrieved on July 1, 2008.</ref>
On March 30–31, 2007 a North American SENS symposium was held in [[Edmonton, Alberta]], Canada as the ''Edmonton Aging Symposium''.<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20160216041842/http://edmontonagingsymposium.com/index.php?pagename=eas_program Program]". Edmonton Aging Symposium. Retrieved on July 1, 2008.</ref> Another SENS-related conference ("Understanding Aging") was held at [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] on June 27–29, 2008<ref>{{cite web|title=Understanding Aging |publisher=Methuselah Foundation |date=2008 |url=http://www.mfoundation.org/UABBA/ |accessdate=2009-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225054539/http://mfoundation.org/UABBA/ |archivedate=February 25, 2009 }}</ref>
Six SENS conferences have been held at [[Queens' College, Cambridge]] in [[England]]. All the conferences were organized by de Grey and all featured world-class researchers in the field of [[Gerontology#Biogerontology|biogerontology]].
*The first SENS conference was held in September 2003 as the ''10th Congress of the International Association of Biomedical Gerontology''<ref>"[http://www.methuselahfoundation.org/files/iabg10/ The International Association of Biomedical Gerontology 10th Congress (September 19–23, 2003)]". Methuselah Foundation. Retrieved on July 1, 2008.</ref> *The fourth SENS conference was held September 3–7, 2009. *The fifth was held August 31 – September 4, 2011, like the first four, it was at Queens' College, Cambridge in England, organized by de Grey.<ref>{{cite web | title = Strategies for Engineered Negligible Senescence (SENS), Fourth Conference| work = SENS4 — Cambridge | publisher = Methuselah Foundation | date = 2008 | url = http://www.mfoundation.org/sens4 | accessdate = 2009-03-02 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Strategies for Engineered Negligible Senescence: Covering the SENS4 conference | work = Research in the biology of aging | publisher = Ouroboros | date = September 3, 2009 | url = http://ouroboros.wordpress.com/2009/09/03/sens4-coverage/ | accessdate = 2009-09-09 }}</ref> Videos of the presentations are [http://www.sens.org/conferences/sens5 available]. *The sixth SENS conference (SENS6) was held from September 3–7, 2013.
Another meeting was held in August 2014 in Santa Clara, California.<ref name=sens6>{{cite web | title = Sixth SENS Conference (SENS6) | url = http://www.sens.org/outreach/conferences/sens6 }}</ref>
== SENS Research Foundation == {{Main|SENS Research Foundation}}
The SENS Research Foundation is a [[non-profit organization]] co-founded by Michael Kope, [[Aubrey de Grey]], Jeff Hall, Sarah Marr and Kevin Perrott, which is based in [[California]], [[United States]]. Its activities include SENS-based research programs and [[public relations]] work for the acceptance of and interest in related research.
Before March 2009, the SENS research programme was mainly pursued by the [[Methuselah Foundation]], co-founded by Aubrey de Grey and David Gobel. The [[Methuselah Foundation]] is most notable for establishing the [[Methuselah Mouse Prize]], a monetary prize awarded to researchers who extend the lifespan of mice to unprecedented lengths.<ref name=MFMission> "[https://web.archive.org/web/20080725074128/http://www.mprize.org/index.php?pagename=mission What is the Methuselah Foundation?]". Methuselah Foundation. Retrieved on July 5, 2008.</ref>
For 2013, The SENS Research Foundation has a research budget of approximately $4 million annually, half of it funded by a personal contribution of $13 million of Aubrey de Grey's<ref>[http://nextbigfuture.com/2013/07/aubrey-de-grey-donates-13-million-of.html Aubrey de Grey] donates $13 million of his own wealth to SENS life extension</ref> own wealth, and the other half coming from external donors, with the largest external donor being [[Peter Thiel]], and another Internet entrepreneur Jason Hope,<ref>Internet Entrepreneur [http://jasonhope.com/press/61-sens-foundation Jason Hope] Pledges A Donation To SENS Foundation</ref> has recently begun to contribute comparable sums.

[[Image:Coffin-bell.gif|thumb|Inventors addressed the fear of being buried alive.]]
'''Fear of being buried alive''' is the [[fear]] of being [[premature burial|placed in a grave while still alive]] as a result of being incorrectly pronounced [[Death|dead]]. The abnormal, [[psychopathology|psychopathological]] version of this fear is referred to as '''taphophobia''' (from [[Greek language|Greek]] τάφος - ''taphos'', "grave, tomb"<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dta%2Ffos1 τάφος], Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus</ref> and φόβος - ''phobos'', "fear"<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dfo%2Fbos φόβος], Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus</ref>), which is translated as "fear of graves".<ref>Dietrich H. "Taphophobia and resurrection mania", ''Schweizer Arkiv für Neurologie, Neurochirurgie und Psychiatrie''. 1977;120(2):195–203 {{PMID|905788}}</ref>
Before the advent of modern medicine, the fear was not entirely irrational. Throughout history, there have been numerous cases of people being buried alive by accident. In 1905, the English reformer [[William Tebb]] collected accounts of premature burial. He found 219 cases of near live burial, 149 actual live burials, 10 cases of live dissection and 2 cases of awakening while being embalmed.<ref>Quigley, Christine. ''The Corpse: A History''</ref>
The 18th century had seen the development of [[Artificial respiration|mouth-to-mouth resuscitation]] and crude [[defibrillation]] techniques to revive persons considered dead, and the [[Royal Humane Society]] had been formed as the Society for the Recovery of Persons Apparently Drowned.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.alcor.org/Library/html/PersonsApparentlyDead.htm |title=The Society for the Recovery of Persons Apparently Dead |author=Steven B. Harris, M.D. |journal=Cryonics |date=September 1990 |accessdate=2006-12-06}}</ref> In 1896, an American funeral director, T. M. Montgomery, reported that "nearly 2% of those exhumed were no doubt victims of suspended animation",<ref>[http://www.snopes.com/horrors/gruesome/buried.asp "Just Dying to Get Out"], from [[Snopes.com]]</ref> although folklorist Paul Barber has argued that the incidence of burial alive has been overestimated, and that the normal effects of decomposition are mistaken for signs of life.<ref>Barber, Paul. ''Vampires, Burial and Death: Folklore and Reality''. Yale University Press, 1988.</ref>
There have been many [[urban legend]]s of people being accidentally buried alive. Legends included elements such as someone entering into the state of [[sopor (sleep)|sopor]] or [[coma]], only to wake up years later and die a horrible death. Other legends tell of coffins opened to find a corpse with a long beard or corpses with the hands raised and palms turned upward. Of note is a legend about the premature burial of Ann Hill Carter Lee, the wife of [[Henry Lee III]].<ref>[http://archive.lewrockwell.com/jarvis/jarvis81.html Robert E. Lee's Mother]</ref> On his deathbed in 1799, [[George Washington]] made his attendants promise not to bury him for two days.
Literature found fertile ground in exploring the natural fear of being buried alive. One of [[Edgar Allan Poe]]'s horror stories, "[[The Premature Burial]]", is about a person suffering from taphophobia. Other Poe stories about premature burial are "[[The Fall of the House of Usher]]" and "[[The Cask of Amontillado]]"—and to a lesser extent, "[[The Black Cat (short story)|The Black Cat]]".
Fear of being buried alive was elaborated to the extent that those who could afford it would make all sorts of arrangements for the construction of a [[safety coffin]]<ref>[http://p6.hostingprod.com/@www.kirchersociety.org/blog/?p=233 A Short History of Security Coffins] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927090943/http://p6.hostingprod.com/@www.kirchersociety.org/blog/?p=233 |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref> to ensure this would be avoided (e.g., glass lids for observation, ropes to bells for signaling, and breathing pipes for survival until rescued).<ref>[http://www.bpmlegal.com/wcoffin.html Improved burial case]</ref>
An urban legend states that the sayings "Saved by the bell" and "Dead ringer" are both derived from the notion of having a rope attached to a bell outside the coffin that could alert people that the recently buried person is not yet deceased; these theories have been proven a hoax.<ref>{{cite book|last=Wilton|first=David|title=Word Myths: Debunking Linguistic Urban Legends|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2009|pages=75–77|isbn=978-0-19-537557-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.snopes.com/language/phrases/1500.asp |title=snopes.com: Life in the 1500s: |publisher=snopes.com |accessdate=2012-08-23 |last=Mikkelson |first=Barbara }}</ref>
Although greater public confidence in the medical profession and its ability to diagnose death accurately has seen a reduction in fear of premature burial after the early 20th century there have been periods of public alarm in recent decades after medical errors in diagnosing death were reported.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Bondeson |first1=Jan |title=Buried Alive: The Terrifying History of Our Most Primal Fear |date=17 March 2002 |publisher=W. W. Norton & Company |location=London |isbn=978-0393322224}}</ref> Taphophobia may remain common in some parts of the world. For example, a study of Pakistani women found severe taphophobia in one third of subjects with mental illness and a mild degree of this fear in half of the controls.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bajwa |first1=Munaza |title=Prevalence and factors associated with phobias among women |journal=Asean Journal of Psychiatry |date=2014 |volume=15 |issue=2 |page=140–145}}</ref> Although rare in the developed world, a recent study reported three cases of taphophobia among older people in the west of Ireland.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fanous |first1=S. |last2=O’Keeffe |first2=S.T. |title=Not yet dead and buried! Three cases of taphophobia in older people |journal=European Geriatric Medicine |date=June 2015 |volume=6 |issue=3 |pages=274–275 |doi=10.1016/j.eurger.2015.01.011}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of phobias]]

page.title: The Order of the Good Death

revision.text:
{{Merge from | Death-positive movement |discuss=Talk:The Order of the Good Death#Merger discussion|date=March 2018 }} '''The Order of the Good Death''' is a [[Death anxiety (psychology)|death acceptance]] organization founded in 2011 by mortician and author [[Caitlin Doughty]].<ref name=Coye2014/><ref name=OConnor2013/><ref name=Washburn2013/> The group advocates for [[natural burial]] and embracing human mortality.<ref>{{citation|title=Natural Burial|publisher=The Order of the Good Death|url=http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/naturalburial|accessdate=2017-05-08}}</ref>
Along with Doughty, members include Sarah Chavez<ref>http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/members</ref>, Director of The Order of the Good Death, Megan Rosenbloom, Director of Death Salon, and Amber Carvaly, Director of Undertaking LA. Other notable members are artist and monument-maker [[Greg Lundgren]], [[TED (conference)|TED speaker]] Jae Rhim Lee, alternative funeral home director Jeff Jorgenson, artist [[Landis Blair]],<ref>http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/members</ref> and other death professionals, artists and academics.<ref name=Gross2014/><ref name=Kiley2014a/><ref name=Kiley2014b/><ref name=Sayles2014/><ref>{{citation|title=Members: Death Professionals|publisher=The Order of the Good Death|url=http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/members/death-professionals|accessdate=2014-12-26}}</ref><ref name=Pompilio2013/>
The group held its first "death [[salon (gathering)|salon]]" in Los Angeles in 2013.<ref name=Hayasaki2013/><ref name=OConnor2013/><ref name=Courtland2014/><ref name=Kellogg2013/><ref name=deathsalon/> Another salon was held in 2014 at [[St Bartholomew's Hospital]] Pathology Museum in London by museum curator Carla Valentine.<ref name=Sherwin2014/>
The group took its name from the Brazilian [[Order of Our Lady of the Good Death]].<ref>{{citation|title=About us|publisher=The Order of the Good Death|url=http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/about|accessdate=2014-12-27|quote=The Order was inspired by several historical concepts of the good death, including the medieval Ars Moriendi (Art of Dying) and the Tibetan Bardo Thodol. The name itself is taken from the 19th century Brazilian sisterhood of African slaves, Irmandade da Nossa Senhora da Boa Morte, or, Sisterhood of Our Lady of the Good Death.}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs=
<ref name=Coye2014> {{citation|title=Seven Sacraments for Everyone | first=Dale F. |last=Coye | publisher=FriesenPress | year=2014 | isbn=9781460231555 | p=199 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EjhHAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA199}}</ref>
<ref name=OConnor2013> {{citation| title=The Death-Positive Movement | author=Kim O'Connor | date=May 16, 2013 |journal=[[Pacific Standard]] | url=https://psmag.com/social-justice/the-death-positive-movement-57768}}</ref>
<ref name=Washburn2013> {{citation|title=Decomposure | first=Michael | last=Washburn | journal=University of Chicago Magazine | date=March–April 2013 | url=http://mag.uchicago.edu/decomposure}}</ref>
<ref name=Kiley2014a> {{Citation |last= Kiley |title= It's Time to Think About Your Demise; An Interview with Caitlin Doughty, Author of Smoke Gets in Your Eyes and Doyenne of Death |first= Brendan |newspaper= [[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |date= September 17, 2014 |url= http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/its-time-to-think-about-your-demise/Content?oid=20613253 |accessdate= September 18, 2014 }}</ref>
<ref name=Kiley2014b> {{citation|title=Enough Talk About Your Youth—Let's Talk About Your Death: Seattle Is at the Forefront of Innovative Thinking About What to Do with Dead Bodies|first=Brendan|last=Kiley|newspaper= [[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |date= September 17, 2014 |url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/enough-talk-about-your-youthandmdashlets-talk-about-your-death/Content?oid=20607997}}</ref>
<ref name=Gross2014> {{Citation |url= https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=352765943 |title= A Mortician Talks Openly About Death, And Wants You To, Too [interview transcript] |publisher=[[NPR]] |last= Gross |first= Terry |authorlink=Terry Gross |date= October 8, 2014 |accessdate= October 29, 2014 }}</ref>
<ref name=Hayasaki2013> {{citation|title=Death Is Having a Moment—Fueled by social networking, the growing "death movement" is a reaction against the sanitization of death that has persisted in American culture since the 1800s" | first=Erika | last=Hayasaki | date=October 25, 2013 | journal=[[The Atlantic]] | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/10/death-is-having-a-moment/280777/}}</ref>
<ref name=Courtland2014> {{citation|title=Caitlin Doughty: The Millennial's Mortician | first=Emma |last=Courtland |date=May 14, 2014 | journal=[[LA Weekly]] | url=http://www.laweekly.com/informer/2014/05/14/caitlin-doughty-the-millennials-mortician}}</ref>
<ref name=Kellogg2013> {{citation|title=It's not too late to get to the Death Salon | date=October 19, 2013| author=Carolyn Kellogg | newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]] | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/oct/19/entertainment/la-et-jc-death-salon-20131017}}</ref>
<ref name=deathsalon> {{citation|title=Death Salon|publisher=The Order of the Good Death|url=http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/death-salon|accessdate=2014-12-27}}</ref>
<ref name=Sherwin2014> {{citation|title=To die for: Death Salon mortality conference - the event meant to help you go out with a bang | newspaper=[[The Independent]] | author=Adam Sherwin | date=April 11, 2014 | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/to-die-for-death-salon-mortality-conference--the-event-meant-to-help-you-go-out-with-a-bang-9255118.html}}</ref>
<ref name=Sayles2014> {{citation|title=Hot topics: Hey funeral directors, move out of the way! | editor=Damon Sayles | work=Funeral Home and Cemetery Executive Briefing|date=December 16, 2014|url=http://www.multibriefs.com/briefs/MV-FuneralEB/MV-FUNERALEB121614.php|accessdate=2014-12-26}}</ref>
<ref name=Pompilio2013> {{citation|author=Natalie Pompilio|title=The Order of the Good Death|publisher=[[Legacy.com]]|date=November 16, 2013|url=http://www.legacy.com/news/in-the-news/the-order-of-the-good-death/1668/}}</ref> }}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox ice hockey player |name = |image = Vitalij Aab.jpg |image_size = 230px |caption = |position = [[Winger (ice hockey)|Wing]] |shoots = Right |height_ft = 6 |height_in = 2 |weight_lb = 198 |team = Free Agent |league = [[Deutsche Eishockey Liga|DEL]] |former_teams = [[Nürnberg Ice Tigers]]
[[Adler Mannheim]]
[[Iserlohn Roosters]]
[[Hamburg Freezers]] |ntl_team = GER |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|11|14|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Karagandy]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]] |draft = |draft_year = |draft_team = |career_start = 1997 |career_end = }} '''Vitalij Aab''' (born November 14, 1979, in [[Karaganda]], [[Soviet Union]]) is a German [[ice hockey]] player who is currently an [[Unrestricted Free Agent]]. He most recently played for the [[Thomas Sabo Ice Tigers]] in the [[Deutsche Eishockey Liga|DEL]].{{cite web|url=http://www.icetigers.de/ICETIGERS/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=518:vitalij-aab-kehrt-nach-nuernberg-zurueck&catid=1:aktuelle-nachrichten&Itemid=76|title=Vitalij Aab returns to Nürnberg|publisher=Thomas Sabo Ice Tigers|language=German|date=2010-05-11|accessdate=2010-05-11|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226201047/http://www.icetigers.de/ICETIGERS/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=518:vitalij-aab-kehrt-nach-nuernberg-zurueck&catid=1:aktuelle-nachrichten&Itemid=76|archivedate=2010-12-26|dead-url=yes|df=}} ==Playing career== Vitalij Aab's professional debut was at the age of 17 for EC Wilhelmshaven. In his second season, he scored 28 points. In 1999, he was promoted into the second division with Wilhelmshaven. Two years later, he transferred to the [[Nuremberg Ice Tigers]], where he played for three years. During this time he played so well that the German national coach called him up to play for the [[Germany men's national ice hockey team|German national ice hockey team]]. Aab had the worst season of his career in 2004–05 with the [[Adler Mannheim]]; he only scored 24 points in 48 games, and therefore received very little ice time at the end of the season.{{cite web|url=http://www.hockeyweb.de/static/spielerportraits/aab_vitalij.htm|title=Vitalij Aab profile|website=Hockeyweb.de|date=2010-05-11|accessdate=2010-05-11|language=German|archivedate=2007-12-19|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219224955/http://www.hockeyweb.de/static/spielerportraits/aab_vitalij.htm|dead-url=no|df=}} He left Mannheim after only one season and switched to the [[Iserlohn Roosters]]. After struggling at first, Aab's performance improved dramatically. At the end of the season, he was the highest scorer in Germany. Before the 2006–07 season, he signed with the [[Hamburg Freezers]].{{cite web|language=German|website=abendblatt.de|date=2006-05-09 |url=http://www.abendblatt.de/daten/2008/09/26/943403.html|title=Vitalij Aab: Forward joins the Freezers|accessdate=2010-05-11}} ==Career statistics== ===Regular season and playoffs=== {| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:center; width:74%" |- bgcolor="#e0e0e0" ! colspan="3" bgcolor="#ffffff" | ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" | ! colspan="5" | [[Regular season]] ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" | ! colspan="5" | [[Playoffs]] |- bgcolor="#e0e0e0" ! {{Infobox scientist | name = Wil M.P. van der Aalst | image = Wil_van_der_Aalst_and_the_process_mining_science,_2016.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Wil van der Aalst and the process mining science, 2016 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|01|29|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Eersel]], [[North Brabant]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|1966|01|29|df=y}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = Dutch | fields = [[Information systems]], [[Workflow management]], [[Petri nets]], [[Process mining]], [[Specification language]]s, and [[Simulation]]. | workplaces = [[RWTH Aachen University]] | alma_mater = | thesis_title = "Timed colored Petri nets and their application to logistics" | thesis_url = | thesis_year = 1992 | doctoral_advisor = [[Jaap Wessels]] and [[Kees van Hee]] | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Workflow patterns]], ProM framework, [[YAWL]], software tools such as Declare, Woflan, XRL, | influences = | influenced = | awards = | website = http://www.padsweb.rwth-aachen.de/wvdaalst/ }} '''Willibrordus Martinus Pancratius van der Aalst''' (born 29 January 1966) is a Dutch computer scientist and full professor at [[RWTH Aachen University]], leading the Process and [[Data Science]] (PADS) group. His research and teaching interests include [[information systems]], [[workflow management]], [[Petri nets]], [[process mining]], [[specification language]]s, and [[simulation]].<ref name="AM09"/> He is also known for his work on [[workflow patterns]].
==Biography== Born in [[Eersel]], [[Netherlands]], van der Aalst received an MSc in [[computing science]] in 1988 at the [[Technische Universiteit Eindhoven]] (TU/e), and a PhD in [[mathematics]] in 1992 with the thesis "Timed colored Petri nets and their application to logistics" under supervision of [[Jaap Wessels]] and [[Kees van Hee]].<ref name="CV">{{cite web | url = http://wwwis.win.tue.nl/~wvdaalst/Cv.pdf | title = Curriculum vitae Wil van der Aalst | date = 2009-05-06 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080323232841/http://wwwis.win.tue.nl/~wvdaalst/aboutme.htm |archive-date=2008-03-23|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
In 1992 he started working at the Eindhoven University of Technology as an assistant professor for the department of Mathematics and Computing Science, where he headed the Specification and Modeling of Information systems (SMIS) research group. 2000 to 2003 he became a part-time full professor at the Computing Science department. And from 2000 to 2006 he was head of the Information Systems department at the Technology Management department of TU/e. Since 2006 he is full professor at the Department of Mathematics & Computer Science of the Eindhoven University of Technology. He also has a part-time appointment in the BPM group of [[Queensland University of Technology]] (QUT).<ref name="AM09">[http://wwwis.win.tue.nl/~wvdaalst/aboutme.htm About Wil van der Aalst] at tue.nl. Accessed May 26, 2009.</ref>
He has been a visiting professor on at [[Karlsruhe Institute of Technology]] (AIFB), the [[University of Georgia]] (LSDIS), [[Johann Wolfgang Goethe University Frankfurt am Main]] (WI-II), the [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]] (CTRG), [[Queensland University of Technology]] (CITI), [[Aarhus University]] (DAIMI),<ref name="CV"/> and Fondazione Bruno Kessler (FBK).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://magazine.fbk.eu/en/news/fbk-hosts-one-of-the-most-cited-scientists-worldwide-in-the-field-of-process-mining/|title=FBK hosts one of the most cited scientists worldwide in the field of process mining|work=FBK Magazine|access-date=2018-04-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
He is associate editor for several journals, including "IEEE Transactions on Services Computing", "IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics", "International Journal of Business Process Integration and Management", "International Journal on Enterprise Modelling and Information Systems Architectures", "Computers in Industry", and "Transactions on Petri Nets and Other Models of Concurrency".<ref name="CV"/>
He is series editor of "Lecture Notes in Business Information Processing" (LNBIP) by Springer, member of the editorial board of "Distributed and Parallel Databases" and "Business and Information Systems Engineering", and member of several steering committees, including "International Conference Series on Business Process Management" (chair), "International Conference Series on Application and Theory of Petri nets" and "International Workshop Series on Web Services and Formal Methods". He is also a member of the Royal Holland Society of Sciences and Humanities ([[Koninklijke Hollandsche Maatschappij der Wetenschappen]]) and the Academy of Europe ([[Academia Europaea]]).<ref name="CV"/> Van der Aalst was elected member of the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.knaw.nl/nl/leden/leden/13802 |title=Wil van der Aalst |publisher=Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences |date= |accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
==Work== Van der Aalst's research interest is in the fields of [[information systems]], [[business process management]], [[simulation]], [[Petri nets]], [[process model]]s, [[workflow management]] systems, verification techniques, [[process mining]], [[enterprise resource planning]] systems, computer supported cooperative work, [[web service]]s, [[business process redesign]], resource allocation and interorganizational [[business process]]es.<ref name="CV"/>
He is a strong supporter of [[open-source software]]. He initiated and led the development of: *the ProM framework, a [[process mining]] tool *[[YAWL]], a workflow management system *and several other software tools including Declare, Woflan, XRL, etc.
He also initiated the [[workflow patterns]] initiative. This work influenced industry standards such as the [[Business Process Execution Language]] (BPEL), the [[Business Process Modeling Notation]] (BPMN), etc. Van der Aalst's ideas have also influenced various widely used commercial software tools such as Flower, Protos, Futura Reflect, Staffware, WebSphere, and [[Architecture of Integrated Information Systems|ARIS]].
Other scientific contributions of Van der Aalst are in the fields of [[Business Process Discovery]], [[event-driven process chain]]s, the [[Workflow Management Coalition]] and [[XPDL]].
Van der Aalst is an [[ISI Highly Cited]] researcher. According to [[Google Scholar]] he is the eight highest ranked computer scientist in the world and 1st among computer scientists not in the US. See [http://www.cs.ucla.edu/~palsberg/h-number.html H-index for computer science].
==Publications== Van der Aalst has published in total more than 400 books, journal papers, book chapters, conference papers, and reports on these topics.<ref>{{DBLP|name=Wil M. P. van der Aalst}}</ref><ref>{{Google Scholar id|name=Wil van der Aalst}}</ref> Books, a selection:
* van der Aalst, Wil, and [[Kees Max Van Hee]]. ''[http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.95.9284&rep=rep1&type=pdf Workflow management: models, methods, and systems].'' MIT press, 2002; 2004. * Dumas, Marlon, Wil M. van der Aalst, and Arthur H. Ter Hofstede. ''Process-aware information systems: bridging people and software through process technology.'' John Wiley & Sons, 2005. * van der Aalst, Wil. ''Process mining: discovery, conformance and enhancement of business processes.'' Springer Science & Business Media, 2011.
Articles, a selection: * van der Aalst, Wil MP. "[http://martinfowler.workflowpatterns.com/documentation/documents/vanderaalst98application.pdf The application of Petri nets to workflow management]." ''Journal of circuits, systems, and computers'' 8.01 (1998): 21-66. * Wil van der Aalst, [[Arthur H.M. Hofstede]], Bartek Kiepuszewski, and Alistair P. Barros (2003). [http://www.w.workflowpatterns.com/documentation/documents/wfs-pat-2002.pdf "Workflow Patterns"]. In: ''Distributed and Parallel Databases'' 14 (1): pp. 5–51. {{doi|10.1023/A:1022883727209}}. * van der Aalst, Wil MP, Arthur HM Ter Hofstede, and Mathias Weske. "Business process management: A survey." ''Business process management.'' Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2003. 1-12. * van der Aalst, Wil MP, and Arthur HM Ter Hofstede. "[http://eprints.qut.edu.au/10244/01/10244.pdf YAWL: yet another workflow language]." ''Information systems'' 30.4 (2005): 245-275.
